DOC.HEAD: `The Cosby Show' Beats `The Simpsons' Again in National Ratings
DOC.TEXT: ``The Cosby Show'' beat Fox Broadcasting Co.'s animated hit ``The Simpsons'' in national ratings for the second straight week, this time by a bigger margin. ``The Cosby Show'' averaged an 18.5 rating and a 29 percent share of the television audience, while ``The Simpsons'' was second with a 16.2 rating and a 25 share, said Preston Beckman, an NBC executive for audience research. As it had last week against the season's first new ``Simpsons'' episode, ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC's perennial ratings winner, finished second in the overnight ratings sample from the biggest media markets. Last week, ``Cosby'' ended up edging ``The Simpsons'' in the national ratings by a tenth of a rating point. Of this week's bigger margin, Beckman said, ``It's a significant victory.'' A rating point equals 931,000 TV households. A share is the percentage of all television sets in use tuned to a show in its time period. After the overnight ratings were reported, Fox spokesman Brad Turrell said, ``These are great results for us.'' Fox executives have said they would be happy if ``The Simpsons'' finished a close second to NBC. ``The more important figure for Fox is in the younger demographics,'' Turrell said. ``In everything (ages) 2 to 54 we will be No. 1 and they will beat us soundly in everything 55 and over. Basically, we won every demo 2 to 54, male and female.'' The A.C. Nielsen Co. conducts overnight ratings in 24 of the nation's largest markets, but technical problems delayed Friday's figures, which covered only 23 markets. Hartford, Conn., was missing from the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Country Music Star Ferlin Husky Undergoes Heart Bypass Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Country music singer Ferlin Husky was in stable condition after triple heart-bypass surgery, a hospital spokeswoman said. ``His doctor thought he was doing well,'' Aileen Katcher of Baptist Hospital. She said Husky will be intensive care for several days. Cardiac surgeon Dr. Robert Hardin performed the surgery Friday. Hardin has performed successful bypasses on Waylon Jennings and Johnny Cash. Husky, who became famous in the 1960s with country hits including ``Wings of Dove,'' suffered from angina, said his wife, Mavis. He also underwent open heart surgery in 1977 and suffered a heart attack in 1983. Chest pains forced him to cancel a benefit concert Saturday in Cody, Wyo. At the height of his career, Husky was a recording, movie and television star. He made 18 movies with such co stars as Jayne Mansfield and Zsa Zsa Gabor. He cut back on his entertaining career in 1970 and has mostly played concert dates.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Argues Jurors Star-Struck in Giving Comedian Damage Award
DOC.TEXT: Jurors were star-struck when they awarded comedian Rodney Dangerfield $500,000 in damages for an eye injury he suffered at Caesars Palace, attorneys for the Las Vegas resort contend. The hotel filed a motion in federal court Thursday asking for a new trial, saying Dangerfield was awarded excessive compensation for a minor injury. ``The jury was obviously too taken with their proximity to fame to be rational to analyze the evidence,'' the motion said. ``The jury utterly disregarded the fact that there was no objective evidence of any continuing injury, no medical expenses past or present, no sign of any permanent injury.'' In awarding Dangerfield $500,000 last month, the jury found that the hotel was responsible for a March 1988 steam bath accident that the comedian said burned his eyes.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats, Republicans Battle Over Tax Burden on Rich
DOC.TEXT: Democrats are unsure whether they can force President Bush to accept higher tax rates on the richest Americans, but gasoline levies seem certain to rise as lawmakers fashion a compromise budget. For Democrats, the start of House-Senate bargaining Friday over the final shape of a $250 billion deficit-reduction bill meant a chance to foist more of its burden onto the wealthy. For Republicans, the goal was to prevent higher income-tax rates and ensure cuts in spending. Bush has threatened repeatedly to veto Democratic attempts to boost the 28 percent tax rate the richest Americans pay to 33 percent. He visited Capitol Hill Friday and urged congressional leaders to send him a compromise quickly. ``I don't know why we have to go through a process of producing a bill that will not be signed,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee. Democrats said it was only fair to spread the pain of deficit-reduction according to taxpayers' ability to pay. But they seemed willing to compromise. ``I hope it's possible to assemble a revenue package that gives a just share of that burden to the wealthiest among us, but does so without violating the president's principles,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The approach of Election Day - barely two weeks off - was clearly raising pressure on the lawmakers to come up with a compromise. But another source of strain was eased when Bush signed an emergency bill keeping the government in business through Wednesday. The president had earlier threatened to shut the government down this morning - when its financing would have expired - unless Congress' budget work was finished. With that distraction aside, lawmakers began seeking middle ground between the Senate's moderate budget and the more liberal version the House adopted earlier last week. ``This is going to have to be carefully drawn,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Their daunting job was symbolized by the legislation itself: a half-foot stack of paper weighing 13 pounds. Republicans rallied around the Senate plan, which doubles the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax, limits deductions for people earning more than $100,000 annually and boosts out-of-pocket costs for Medicare recipients. ``This is a balanced bill,'' said Domenici. ``It is progressive.'' But House Speaker Thomas Foley said Democrats wanted the Senate to moderate its gasoline tax increase and its steeper increases in out-of-pocket Medicare costs for beneficiaries. He also noted that Democrats remain behind the House bill's higher taxes on the rich. Besides the higher income-tax rate for wealthy Americans, it puts a 10 percent surtax on people earning $1 million annually. ``Obviously, compromises are required,'' Foley, a Washington Democrat, told reporters. ``The insistence of the president on having no income tax changes (affecting the rich) seems to be inexplicable and inflexible.'' Republicans strongly oppose a House provision that would, in effect, cause slight income-tax increases on most Americans. It would delay for one year the inflation adjustment made in tax brackets and the personal exemption. Democrats have said that provision is likely to be altered or eliminated. Both the House and Senate bills would increase taxes on tobacco, alcohol, airline tickets and luxury items such as private planes. Both would enlarge tax credits for low-income people. The legislation is the keystone of a plan aimed at cutting the deficit by $500 billion over the next five years. The rest of the savings would arise by slashing the Pentagon budget, and from lower-than-anticipated interest payments on the national debt.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Admits Error in Insurance Study
DOC.TEXT: The consumer organization Public Citizen says it made an error in placing the ITT Hartford Insurance group on a list of companies it said were in danger of insolvency in a recession. ``The Hartford should not have been included among the companies most financially vulnerable in a severe economic downturn,'' Public Citizen President Joan Claybrook said Friday. ``We regret this error and will take steps to correct it,'' she said in a letter to Hartford Chairman Donald R. Frahm. Public Citizen did say it remains convinced that property and casualty insurance companies need to improve their business practices. Public Ciizen said in a report issued Monday the Hartford and four other companies failed four of six tests measuring how vulnerable their were to insolvency. The original report said the Hartford's surplus funds declined 33 percent from 1972 to 1988. The surplus actually grew 6 percent, she said. The error was discovered by ITT Hartford and confirmed by its independent auditors, Arthur Andersen & Co. In preparing its report, Public Citizen relied on financial data in an industry publication. Jim Westervelt, vice president and group comptroller for the Hartford, said the 1972 figure appearing in the publication represented the surpluses of all of the Hartford companies. The 1988 figure represented only the consolidated surpluses of Hartford Fire Insurance Company and its property and casualty subsidiaries, he said. In Baltimore, another company that appeared on the list, United States Fidelity & Guaranty, issued a statement calling Public Citizen's report ``misdirected and shallow.'' The company said the report ``misapplied critical financial data relating to USF&G and overlooked other financial information.'' ``USF&G's own analysis contradicts Public Citizen's conclusions and establishes that USF&G falls safely within the group of other financially strong insurers analyzed in the report who were not singled out,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Two American MIAs Buried After 19 Years In Laos
DOC.TEXT: Three young people said farewell to the fathers they never knew, almost two decades after the two men were killed in Laos in the last major offensive of the Vietnam War. ``It has been a long time - their children were infants when they died,'' Chaplain Lt. Col. John Morrison said Friday at the burial ceremony in Arlington National Cemetery. A chain of POW-MIA bracelets was draped over the casket of Capt. Keith A. Brandt of Bellingham, Wash., a helicopter pilot who died along the Xe Pon River in March 1971 while trying to rescue stranded South Vietnamese soldiers. Lt. Alan B. Boffman of Norfolk, Va., co-pilot of Brandt's helicopter, was buried in the same ceremony. Don George of Vietnam Veterans of America Chapter 165 of Bellingham said it was difficult to give up his POW-MIA bracelet. ``I had always hoped and wished he would come back alive,'' George said. ``I guess the odds were not in favor of that but you do hope and hope and hope.'' Family members declined to talk to reporters. George said, though, that the captain's brother, Garth Brandt, told him, ``Now we don't have to worry anymore. We know he's back home.'' Brandt, a pilot who was 31 at the time of his death, was the leader of an attack helicopter section of the 101st Aviation Battalion Company D. He and Boffman, age 24, volunteered to lead rescuers to the bomb crater where survivors of the 420-member South Vietnamese battalion had retreated. At a private funeral Friday at Fort Meyer, Va., Morrison said, he spoke with Brandt's sons, Eric, 21, and Garth, 19, of Mill Creek, Wash., and Boffman's daughter, Carla, of Fayetteville, N.C. He said he told them to be proud of their fathers. ``I indicated to the children that we knew they would always honor their dads' supreme sacrifice and that this service was for the rest of the nation to honor them,'' he said. Also attending the service were Brandt's widow, Donna Hager of Mill Creek, and mother, Lorraine Brandt of Bellingham, as well as Boffman's widow, Jean Boffman Williams of Fayetteville, and mother, Bessie Boffman of Baltimore, Md. A single casket with the remains of both men was brought to the burial site in a procession with a military band, color guard and two riderless horses. After a 21-gun salute, Mrs. Williams wiped away tears as the band played ``Taps'' and ``America the Beautiful.'' George later took the bracelets to the Vietnam Memorial in Washington. He left a message on a paper napkin that he said he scribbled when he awoke in the middle of the night Thursday: ``Sleep in peace at last in the soil of your native country, which will always remember gratefully your supreme sacrifice in the course of fulfilling your duty for God and country.''

DOC.HEAD: Field Where Wrights Learned To Fly Dedicated as Historic Landmark
DOC.TEXT: The meadow where Orville and Wilbur Wright learned to turn and maneuver the world's first airplanes has been dedicated as a national historic landmark. With a replica of one of Wright brothers' planes buzzing overhead, about 400 military and civilian dignitaries attended the dedication ceremony Friday at the Huffman Prairie Flying Field on Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. The Wright brothers first flew at Kitty Hawk, N.C., on Dec. 17, 1903. They then returned to Dayton and learned to maneuver the aircraft at Huffman Prairie. ``They spent almost the whole year learning how to turn it and control it,'' said base historian Lois Walker. ``The very first circle in powered flight history was made on Sept. 20, 1904.'' The 84-acre field was designated an historic landmark last July.

DOC.HEAD: Fort Smith-Area Colonel Says He Provided Mailing Labels
DOC.TEXT: The campaign of Republican gubernatorial candidate Sheffield Nelson obtained an address list from the Arkansas National Guard and used it to mail 10,000 letters. The guard has launched an inquiry into the matter, which involves a colonel. Maj. Gen. James A. Ryan, the guard's adjutant general, said the release violated federal privacy laws. Nelson said the guard inquiry was motivated by politics. His opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, appointed Ryan. Nelson also has questioned the credibility of the inquiry because the guard never called him or his office about the labels. ``Let me say on the record: this was not leaked. This was not a devious act,'' Nelson spokesman John Hudgens said Friday. ``We assumed if the guy had the list anybody could get it. All you had to do was ask for it.'' Shefield's mailing sought support of Arkansas guardsmen. The envelopes were addressed with computer-generated labels that included the names, addresses and unit identification codes of guardsmen.
DOC.HEAD: Magazine Alleges Past Drug Use by Congressman
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Dana Rohrabacher repeatedly used marijuana and experimented with LSD as a young man, according to New Republic magazine. Rohrabacher is seeking re-election and is a supporter of strong anti-drug legislation. The Republican congressman condemned the article as ``character assassination.'' His district includes parts of Los Angeles and Orange counties. The story in the political journal's Nov. 5 issue, entitled ``The Dope on Dana,'' also contends that Rohrabacher agreed to refrain from ``noisy anti-drug crusading'' if friends remained quiet about his past drug use. With one exception, the article cites anonymous sources regarding Rohrabacher's alleged drug use, which purportedly occurred during a time when he backed the legalization of drugs and espoused anarchy. The congressman claimed he was a New Republic target because of his battle against the National Endowment for the Arts and federal funding of what he deems obscene or offensive art.
DOC.HEAD: Here Come Norm and Woody From `Cheers'
DOC.TEXT: Gregory Jolivette is hoping a heavy, beer-swilling, often-unemployed barfly and country bumpkin bartender can help him win a seat in Congress. The actors who portray Norm and Woody on television's ``Cheers'' are headlining a combination comedy show and campaign rally that will be the biggest event of the Ohio Democrat's race against John Boehner. The event is scheduled for Nov. 3, three days before the election. Actor George Wendt, best known for the ``Norm'' character, is Jolivette's brother-in-law. Wendt will appear with fellow ``Cheers'' actor Woody Harrelson and game show host Ray Combs. Combs is from Jolivette's hometown of Hamilton, Ohio, and Harrelson is from nearby Lebanon, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Ethics Panel Member Impatient Over Keating Case
DOC.TEXT: A Senate Ethics Committee member is accusing others on the panel of unfairly prolonging an investigation into the relationship of five senators with former S&L executive Charles H. Keating Jr. ``If I were any one of the five, I would be going ballistic - it's just not fair,'' Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., said Friday. His remarks were a break with the usual reticence of committee members to comment on a case. Lott spoke after the committee failed for the second straight day to make crucial decisions in the probe. The committee is weighing its special counsel's proposal to proceed with its investigation of Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. The counsel proposed to drop the probe of Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz. and John Glenn, D-Ohio. Lott said he could not remain silent because, ``I feel like I've been an accomplice to a crime.'' He added he's ``extremely pessimistic'' that the committee will be able to make a decision when it meets next week. The panel is trying to determine if there was a connection between the $1.3 million in political contributions Keating and associates gave the senators' campaigns and causes and their intervention with banking regulators on his behalf. Many of the contacts came when Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan was headed toward collapse. It was seized by the government in April 1989 and taxpayers could have to pay more than $2 billion to make up for the losses. One source who spoke on condition of anonymity said that disagreement is expected over Riegle's fate, with at least one senator inclined to drop him from the investigation along with Glenn and McCain. ``What's important is whether he intervened after'' an April 9, 1987, meeting with banking regulators when the five senators were told there may have been criminal violations at Lincoln, the source said. DeConcini and Cranston kept up their contacts with regulators after that date. Riegle, McCain and Glenn did not. Glenn, asked about the rate of progress, said, ``I've been frustrated for a year.'' McCain said Friday, ``I'm deeply disappointed they haven't been able to act. They owe the American people an explanation of why they haven't.'' The decision on McCain is especially important because if he is dropped from the investigation before the Nov. 6 election, only Democrats would be subjects of the inquiry. That could give Republicans a campaign issue to counter Democratic charges that the GOP is responsible for the savings and loan crisis. Lott said he has no evidence that partisan motives are delaying the process, saying, ``I don't know what the motives are. I can't believe that (partisanship) is involved here.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Chief Signals Veto of Military Spending Bill
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, upset with deep cuts in strategic weapons, is inclined to recommend a presidential veto of a $288 billion military spending package, lawmakers say. A Defense Department official confirmed Friday that the Pentagon has told lawmakers Cheney is leaning toward recommending a veto of the 1991 military spending bill. Cheney has not reached a final decision, however, and still hopes changes will be made before the House and Senate take up the bill, possibly as early as Sunday, the official said. Cheney was visiting France today on the final leg of a 10-day trip that included Britain and the Soviet Union. Aides are keeping him posted on details of the bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Rep. Jon L. Kyl, R-Ariz., said he heard ``from people who ought to know'' that Cheney will recommend a veto. Kyl is one of 15 Republicans who were involved in negotiations on the bill but refused to sign the final package. The bill sets military spending at $288 billion for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and represents a $19 billion reduction from President Bush's request last January. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said he spoke with Bush while the president was visiting Capitol Hill on Friday and urged him to sign the bill. ``Afterward I had a chance to consult with senior staff and in the brief exchange they reinforced my conviction that he will sign the legislation,'' the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee said. The Pentagon has criticized several provisions, including cuts in troop levels and the budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The bill provides $2.9 billion for SDI, nearly $2 billion less than Bush requested and $900 million below the level Congress provided last year for the proposed anti-missile shield commonly known as Star Wars. The measure also cuts 100,000 troops from the 2.1 million now in uniform worldwide. Cheney had urged Congress to hold the cuts to 80,000. Meanwhile, 22 House Republicans wrote to the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee criticizing the exclusion of the panel's ranking Republican from the final days of negotiations. Rep. Bill Dickinson, R-Ala., was not included in a late-night session Tuesday involving Nunn, Warner and Aspin in which the final defense package was produced. In an interview, Aspin said Dickinson was excluded from a session that dealt with minor issues because he had indicated he would oppose the bill. Aspin said he did not want Dickinson ``over here throwing rocks.'' Elsewhere, the House by voice vote adopted the bill that provides $8.4 billion for military construction and family housing in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The package is $764 million less than what Bush sought. In a step certain to rile the president, the bill bars spending any federal funds from the NATO Infrastructure Fund for building a base in Crotone, Italy, for the Air Force's 401st Tactical Wing. The bill slashes the administration's request for the NATO Infrastructure Fund from $420 million to $193 million. Spain has said the wing of 72 F-16 jet fighters must be moved from Torrejon de Ardoz, and Italy agreed two years ago to provide a new home under NATO auspices. Lawmakers have questioned the wisdom of constructing a base in Europe when Cheney plans to close others overseas and at home.

DOC.HEAD: Essence Magazine Celebrates 20th Anniversary With Radio City Gala
DOC.TEXT: Essence magazine celebrated its 20th anniversary by honoring six African-American women, including Grammy-winning singer Whitney Houston and actress Diahann Carroll, at a star-studded gala Friday night. The ceremony before 6,000 people at sold-out Radio City Music Hall also honored Gospel singer Shirley Caesar, dancer and anthropologist Katherine Dunham, singer Patti LaBelle and diva Leontyne Price. Bill Cosby was host of the event. Singer Stephanie Mills, talk show host Oprah Winfrey, the Dance Theatre of Harlem and singer Freddie Jackson joined him on stage. Special tribute was paid to Winnie Mandela and the late Sarah Vaughan, the singer known as ``Sassy.'' Mandela, wife of South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela, received standing ovations as she stood onstage, her arm raised in the black power salute. She accepted her award in the name of the African National Congress, which her husband leads. ``I thank you very much for restoring the dignity of a brutalized woman,'' she told the gathering. Short of money and with little publishing experience, four black men in May 1970 launched Essence magazine, aimed at black women. The country was in a recession at the time, co-founder and publisher Edward Lewis recalled, and the founders were able to find only $130,000 of the $1.5 million they thought they needed to start a magazine. ``It was hard work, sheer determination, a little bit of luck,'' Lewis said. ``We were able to weather all of those storms. The idea of a magazine for black women just caught on.'' Starting with a circulation of about 50,000, Essence now claims a readership of 4 million based upon a circulation of 800,000. Essence celebrates its 20th anniversary during the same year Black Enterprise magazine hit 20 and Ebony 45. Essence had revenues of $19.8 million in 1989 and Essence Communications Inc. had total revenues of $38 million. Essence also had a television show for four years, is set to launch a second product catalog, has a line of eyewear - and, soon, pantyhose - designed specifically for African-Americans. Essence has seen its advertising thin out recently, but that seems part of an industry-wide slump. ``That's the only thing that makes me feel good about it - everybody's hurting,'' laughed Lewis.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Faces Ban for Comparing Mohammed with Celebrities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name cq for Suharto and Subrata
DOC.TEXT: The government of this mainly Moslem country is considering banning a weekly tabloid for listing the prophet Mohammed with other ``admirable public figures.'' ``The article hurt Moslems' feelings and could lead to religious conflicts,'' Director General for Press and Graphics Subrata said in a statement Friday. This week's issue of the 400,000-circulation tabloid Exemplars contains an article listing 50 well-known figures including Mohammed, President Suharto, Cabinet ministers, film stars and singers. Subrata said the tabloid could be banned after the Information Ministry consults with the country's press council. Indonesia, the world's most populous Moslem nation, prohibits publishing material that could trigger religious or racial disturbances. ``Prophet Mohammed is not a common figure. Therefore, it is not proper to compare him with film stars or other figures,'' said Hamdan Abbas, a senior Moslem scholar. The newspaper's chief editor, Arswendo Atmowiloto, apologized and said the publication would take more care in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Abandon Effort To Reattach Foot Temporarily Sewn To Forearm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note content
DOC.TEXT: Doctors kept a man's severed foot healthy for months by temporarily sewing it to his forearm, but infection forced them to abandon efforts to reattach the foot to the man's leg. The foot, severed in an accident, was reattached to the man's leg Oct. 10. But the two plastic surgeons said Friday that the foot had to be removed because of infection. Drs. Serge Baux and Maurice Mimoun said the health of the 40-year-old patient was satisfactory. The patient, whose name has not been disclosed, fell from a subway platform last March as a train was pulling into the station. His foot was cleanly severed, and rescue workers packed it in ice. Mimoun decided to graft the foot to the man's forearm so that blood would keep flowing to the foot while the stump on the patient's leg healed.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Program Launched For Orphaned, Handicapped Children
DOC.TEXT: The International Red Cross says it will step up efforts to help organize Christmas celebrations for about 130,000 Romanian children in orphanages and institutions. The League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies on Friday announced plans to ship winter clothes, blankets, basic drugs and possibly heating equipment to Romania in a winter aid program worth at least $3 million. Red Cross officials said they will also help organize holiday activities in hopes of getting local people involved with the neglected children, living in about 400 homes established under former dictator Nicolae Ceasescu. Some officials estimate up to 1,000 of the children have acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Ceasescu, executed in last December's revolution, prohibited birth control and abortions under a policy aimed at boosting Romania's population.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates To Receive Equal Time On Air
DOC.TEXT: More than a dozen presidential candidates will be allotted free and equal campaign time on the nation's state-run broadcast media. Candidates must equally divide a total of 15 hours on Poland's two state television channels and 30 hours on the four government-controlled radio stations, the National Electoral Committee and the Radio and Television Committee said Thursday. The broadcast time limits begin Friday at noon - 12 hours after the full list of registered candidates is announced - and remain until Nov. 23. The election is Nov. 25. There are 14 would-be candidates in the race to be the country's first popularly elected president. At least 100,000 signatures must be collected by Thursday to make the ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Drugs Seized Off Puerto Rico
DOC.TEXT: More than $15 million in cocaine and marijuana seized by U.S. officials have been taken to a naval base along with 10 people arrested on drug charges, the U.S. Coast Guard said. The drugs - 4,000 pounds of marijuana and 1,400 pounds of cocaine - were discovered earlier this week in searches of two ships off Puerto Rico. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration said the cocaine had a street value of $12.7 million, and the marijuana was worth between $2.8 million and $4.8 million. The drugs, the two unregistered vessels and 10 detained crewmen captured off the coast Sunday and Monday were transported to Roosevelt Roads Naval Base on Puerto Rico on Friday, the Coast Guard said.

DOC.HEAD: New Weapon For Desert Troops
DOC.TEXT: A businessman is working to equip U.S. troops in the Middle East with a special tool for fighting a pesky enemy that can't be brought down easily with an M-16. Charlie Tapley has gathered 800 plastic fly swatters and is searching for 1,700 more. The owner of Do-It-Yourself Pest Control in Columbus,also is sending the Army about 1,000 fly mats, sticky boards that capture flies, to be used around mess tents. The weapons will be sent to Fort Benning and then on to Saudi Arabia for the troops. Tapley was tipped to the need for his product by Ranger 1st Sgt. Darryl Powell, who recently returned from two months in the desert. ``Flies are everywhere,'' Powell said. ``And we're short of weapons.'' Powell said soldiers play games with the flies at night, seeing how many of the pests they can kill in an hour. ``And rolled-up newspapers just don't get the job done,'' Powell said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: MTV host ``Downtown'' Julie Brown will share her pop culture insights with the syndicated television program ``Inside Edition,'' judging what's hip on a weekly segment. Brown will pronounce sentence on the latest fads in the segment called ``What's In and What's Out,'' scheduled for broadcast on Fridays. The British-born Brown, host of ``Club MTV'' on the music television network, began her career in England working on ``Top of the Pops.'' ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Foul-mouthed comedian Andrew Dice Clay will earn about $500,000 for three nights of shows at Bally's Hotel in Las Vegas in December, his agent said. The full contract, which extends over 18 months and is worth more than $1 million, requires Clay to perform about 30 shows in Bally's hotels in Las Vegas and Reno, agent Dennis Arfa said Thursday. The first shows under the deal will be Dec. 29, 30 and 31. Clay played to sellout crowds in Las Vegas in August. ---= NEW HAVEN, Conn. (AP) - Marilyn Quayle took a break from campaigning for two Republican candidates to visit cancer patients. Promoting cancer awareness and prevention ``is a memorial to my mother,'' said Mrs. Quayle, whose mother died of breast cancer. The 41-year-old wife of Vice President Dan Quayle also is promoting increased awareness of cervical cancer after undergoing a hysterectomy last summer. Doctors had found pre-cancerous cells during a routine exam. Earlier Friday, Mrs. Quayle campaigned for gubernatorial candidate John G. Rowland and congressional candidate Tom Scott. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Kirk Douglas will receive a lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute. Douglas, 74, has appeared in 75 films, including ``Spartacus,'' ``Lust for Life,'' ``Champion,'' and ``Lonely Are The Brave.'' He also has directed and produced movies. The award, previously given to Jack Lemmon, Lillian Gish, Gregory Peck and James Stewart, among 14 others, will be presented March 7. Douglas has written two books, an autobiography called ``The Ragman's Son,'' and a novel, ``Dance With the Devil.'' AFI is a national trust dedicated to preserving the heritage of film and television. ---= FREMONT, Calif. (AP) - Rapper M.C. Hammer, singer of the hit ``U Can't Touch This,'' is buying a $5 million ``Beverly Hills type of house'' in the San Francisco Bay area. The 12.5-acre property features an 11,000-square-foot, V-shaped house with three master bedrooms, a recording studio, a rehearsal hall, a media room, a gym and four dishwashers. The one-story home in the Fremont hills, about 15 miles north of San Jose, also has two swimming pools, a reflecting pool and a nine-car garage. Fremont developer John Dyer described the estate as a ``Beverly Hills type of house.'' Hammer, 27, grew up in an East Oakland housing project and has lived in Fremont for five years. The new house will replace his $750,000 four-bedroom home. He hit it big with the album ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em,'' which has sold 7 million copies. ---= NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country music singer Vern Gosdin was released from the hospital one week after undergoing heart bypass surgery. Gosdin, 56, whose recordings include ``Chiseled In Stone,'' said he hopes to resume performing in eight weeks. Gosdin was admitted to Baptist Hospital Oct. 11 after suffering chest pains and had surgery the next day. He was released Friday. ---= PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) - Two of Martha ``Sunny'' von Bulow's children denounced the movie ``Reversal of Fortune,'' which they say portrays their mother as a sloppy drunk obsessed with drugs. The heiress has been in a coma in New York since 1980. Her husband, Claus von Bulow, was convicted of trying to murder her, but was later retried and acquitted. ``Our mother ... is unable to respond to an assault on her character and reputation,'' Ala Isham and Alexander Auersperg said in a statement. Her children have not seen the movie, but read an early copy of the script, their spokeswoman, Maureen Connelly, said Friday from New York. ``Reversal of Fortune,'' starring Glenn Close as Mrs. von Bulow, portrays the heiress as a heavy drinker and a drug user. The movie opened in limited release Wednesday. ``We reject this injurious and erroneous portrayal and ask the public to do the same in the knowledge that our now defenseless mother was warm and caring and devoted to her family,'' Isham and Auersperg said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Bankers Meet as Clouds Gather Over Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Facing myriad problems in their industry and a slumping economy, the nation's bankers are gathering for five days of brainstorming and image-polishing starting today. One indication of the industry's woes: Some of the country's top banks are saving money by not sending representatives to the American Bankers Association convention. Projected attendance is 4,500, down about 18 percent from last year's meeting. Strategies for steering through the current crises are high on the agenda. Bankers will hear from their colleagues, Wall Street analysts and government officials including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and William L. Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Among those skipping the convention is North Carolina-based NCNB Corp., the Southeast's largest bank. ``It's an important gathering, but we're having to make some hard choices,'' said spokesman John Kleghorn. NCNB this week reported third quarter net income down 60 percent from the same period a year ago. Association President Kelly Holthus said bankers are concerned about maintaining public confidence in the face of a barrage of headlines detailing the industry's troubles. The convention usually attracts wide media coverage. ``A lot of bankers are interested in getting the word out about the credibility of our industry,'' said Holthus. Holtus believes banks' problems have been exaggerated. ``As far as I'm concerned, there are some isolated areas having problems with the economy. And banks always are a mirror of the economy,'' said Holthus, president and chief executive officer of the First National Bank of York, Neb. The meeting comes amid a flurry of worrisome third quarter earnings reports, reduced dividends, layoffs and a drop in the government's deposit insurance fund. And many economists believe the economy is in a recession. A decline in the real estate market and a spate of bad loans have plagued U.S. banks in recent months. Some of the largest banks have reported quarterly losses, and many others have seen profit levels shrink as they divert funds into reserves set aside to cover future loan losses. The Bush administration, meanwhile, predicted earlier this month that bank failures would reduce the FDIC's commercial bank fund by $6.1 billion during the next three years. Those attending the Orlando meeting are likely to fret over the possibility of increased government regulation, said Katherine Bissette, an analyst at Interstate Johnson Lane in Atlanta. ``All in all, what has happened is the industry and the marketplace has been reminded that banking is a regulated industry,'' Ms. Bissette said. ``In the '80s they'd obviously forgotten it, but now you're being hit over the head with it.'' A tighter regulatory environment could be devastating to banks already struggling, she said. ``The good banks are not going to have to worry about it, but the weaker banks - how are they going to do?'' Ms. Bissette asked. ``The pressure is on them at a time when they can least take it.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Will Destroy Racist Recordings Imitating `Mister Rogers'
DOC.TEXT: Three men have agreed to destroy recordings of racist and anti-gay telephone messages that imitated the voice and speech of ``Mister Rogers'' from the children's television program. The men signed settlement agreements Friday with Fred M. Rogers and his Family Communications Inc., owners of the trademarks and copyrights that protect the show. Rogers and Family Communications sued the men - Adam Troy Mercer, Edward E. Stephens IV and Michael Brooks - and the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan last week in federal court to stop the playing of the tape-recorded messages. Mercer, Stephens and Brooks agreed to destroy the tapes and not use any materials that imitate the show. The men said in their agreements that they were not Klan members. Two weeks ago, a group of religious, civil rights and community leaders denounced recordings that callers heard when they dialed an Independence telephone number. They said the number had been widely circulated among schoolchildren in the metropolitan area. The number is the same used earlier this year to promote the philosophy of the Missouri Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. The recordings imitated the sound effects and theme song of the ``Mister Rogers Neighborhood'' show and Rogers' voice and speech patterns.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Ends 13-Day Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Kim Dae-jung ended a 13-day hunger strike today after the governing party agreed to accept one of his key demands - early local government elections. Kim and 69 other opposition lawmakers said, however, they will continue to boycott the National Assembly until the governing Democratic Liberal Party has fully accepted other demands for wider democratic reform. ``My struggle has paid off. I am ending the fast on recommendation by our national assemblymen,'' Kim said at Seoul's Severance Hospital. The 66-year-old opposition leader, who began the hunger strike Oct. 8, was admitted to the hospital Monday in deteriorating health. He continued the hunger strike under 24-hour medical observation. Doctors said Kim has lost about 13 pounds. Kim, leader of the Party for Peace and Democracy, said the government had bowed to his demand for democratic reform and agreed to hold local government elections before the next presidential election, expected in late 1992. All local governments now are under the control of the central government, and there is no local autonomy. The ruling party also agreed to his demand not to change the form of government from presidential to parliamentary ``as long as people and the opposition oppose it,'' he said. Dozens of opposition lawmakers joined Kim's hunger strike early this week. They gave up their fast after Kim ended his hunger strike. Earlier today, Kim Young-sam, chairman of the governing party, publicly accepted some of the key opposition demands, including local elections. ``When I visited him (Kim Dae-jung) at his hospital bed, I also assured him that there would be no forceful attempt to change the constitution to change the form of government,'' Kim Young-sam said in the southern port city of Pusan. The decision defused political tension that has been rising since all 78 opposition lawmakers tendered their resignations in protest of what they called the government's railroading of several controversial bills in July. The opposition charged that one bill was aimed at tightening government control over the nation's broadcasting industry before the next presidential elections. Opposition members said they will continue to boycott the Assembly until those controversial laws were rescinded. They also demanded the reorganization of the powerful military intelligence group, the Military Security Command, which allegedly has spied on civilians. Kim Dae-jung and other opposition members believe that they would stand a better chance of winning power if local governments become autonomous through elections. Kim is expected to run again for president in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Paramedic Answers Call For Fatally Injured Daughter
DOC.TEXT: At the same time a paramedic's wife called him at work to tell him their young daughter had been struck by a car and seriously injured, his ambulance was dispatched to help the girl. ``I don't think anybody can begin to picture what was going through his mind or how he felt. It would be really tough,'' said Lt. Larry Maxwell, a Sedgwick County Emergency Medical Service supervisor. The girl died the next day. David White was ending his shift as an emergency medical technician at a north Wichita fire station Tuesday when his wife called. As she told him 4-year-old Kristina had been hit by a car, the 911 dispatcher announced the call for his ambulance crew. The crew scheduled for the next shift got on the ambulance with White. ``He wasn't going to get off,'' Maxwell said. ``The crew knew David wouldn't be able to run the call. But they did allow his participation as much as they felt comfortable.'' Kristina had been walking along the street where she lived in a Wichita suburb. A 61-year-old woman driving the same direction struck her. The accident was under investigation. Kristina had severe head, internal and leg injuries. White rode with his daughter to a hospital, where she died Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Dress up and Pay 15 Rubles to See Scarlett and Rhett
LaserPhoto MOSB11
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is looking to the West for economic ideas, and an American media mogul says it should look to the Deep South for inspiration to carry out changes. ``The spirit of Scarlett O'Hara is what the Russian people need right now,'' Ted Turner said Friday night before introducing the film ``Gone With The Wind'' to a Soviet audience. ``Because they're going through a huge transition, they have to do like she did (and say) `With God as my witness, I'll never be hungry again,' and go to work to rebuild their country with a new economic system. You can't sit around ... moaning and groaning about the days that are gone.'' The Soviet debut of the 1939 epic had all the glitz of a Hollywood opening - popping flashbulbs, furs and limousines. Movie fans lined up for at least two hours for the chance to pay 15 rubles, $25 at the official exchange rate. The average monthly paycheck is 250 rubles. After the box office sold out, a couple dozen Soviets began offering to scalp their seats for 25 rubles each. The film began an indefinite engagement in Moscow under the sponsorship of a British-Soviet venture and Turner, whose Cable News Network and Goodwill Games are already known to the Soviets. A Red Army band played outside the 2,500-seat Oktyabr theater and moviegoers were treated to a yellow champagne-lookalike before the opening. The VIPs got the real stuff - with caviar - behind a guarded door. Hundreds of people jammed the sidewalk in front of the theater on one of Moscow's main thoroughfares for a chance to view what Turner called the American equivalent of Tolstoy's ``War and Peace,'' another tale of lives torn asunder by a great war. The film retained the original soundtrack with Russian-language subtitles. ``Gone With The Wind'' is set during the Civil War, the same years in which serfdom was abolished in czarist Russia. In its review of the film, the Soviet news agency Tass said ``it will turn the attention of our contemporaries to the beauty of noble feelings.'' Soviets seem to crave anything foreign, particularly American, whether noble or banal. The lines outside ``Gone with the Wind'' were similar to those at the McDonald's and Pizza Hut restaurants that opened this year in Moscow. Formal black-tie attire was optional for this premiere; the movie's organizers guessed that in a country where a sale of tennis shoes can cause a near riot, most people had never even seen a dinner jacket up close. But many Soviet guests dressed snazzily for the occasion. Some wore Italian suits and formal gowns. Others were draped in furs and silk of the sort unseen in ordinary Soviet stores. Once inside, the Soviets could buy an English-language biography of Vivien Leigh, who played the inimitable Scarlett in the film, or a small, 60-ruble bottle of French perfume packaged for the premiere and called ``Scarlett.'' Proceeds were to go to an anti-AIDS benefit sponsored by the liberal weekly magazine Ogonyok. The Soviet-British Creative Association, the joint-venture that organized the showing, says the film will travel to other Soviet cities after Moscow. Turner, whose MGM Film Library owns the rights to the film, came to Moscow with actress Jane Fonda. Fonda, a fitness fanatic, on Thursday led about 700 Soviet women in a jog around the Kremlin.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Chief Signals Veto of Military Spending Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 12-13 grafs pvs Meanwhile x x x produced. to include first reference to Nunn and Aspin. Pickup 14th graf pvs: In an etc.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, upset with deep cuts in strategic weapons, is inclined to recommend a presidential veto of a $288 billion military spending package, lawmakers say. A Defense Department official confirmed Friday that the Pentagon has told lawmakers Cheney is leaning toward recommending a veto of the 1991 military spending bill. Cheney has not reached a final decision, however, and still hopes changes will be made before the House and Senate take up the bill, possibly as early as Sunday, the official said. Cheney was visiting France today on the final leg of a 10-day trip that included Britain and the Soviet Union. Aides are keeping him posted on details of the bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Rep. Jon L. Kyl, R-Ariz., said he heard ``from people who ought to know'' that Cheney will recommend a veo. Kyl is one of 15 Republicans who were involved in negotiations on the bill but refused to sign the final package. The bill sets military spending at $288 billion for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and represents a $19 billion reduction from President Bush's request last January. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said he spoke with Bush while the president was visiting Capitol Hill on Friday and urged him to sign the bill. ``Afterward I had a chance to consult with senior staff and in the brief exchange they reinforced my conviction that he will sign the legislation,'' the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee said. The Pentagon has criticized several provisions, including cuts in troop levels and the budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The bill provides $2.9 billion for SDI, nearly $2 billion less than Bush requested and $900 million below the level Congress provided last year for the proposed anti-missile shield commonly known as Star Wars. The measure also cuts 100,000 troops from the 2.1 million now in uniform worldwide. Cheney had urged Congress to hold the cuts to 80,000. Meanwhile, 22 House Republicans wrote Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, criticizing the exclusion of the panel's ranking Republican from the final days of negotiations. Rep. Bill Dickinson, R-Ala., was not included in a late-night session attended Tuesday by Aspin, Warner and Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, in which the final defense package was produced. In an interview, Aspin said Dickinson was excluded from a session that dealt with minor issues because he had indicated he would oppose the bill. Aspin said he did not want Dickinson ``over here throwing rocks.'' Elsewhere, the House by voice vote adopted the bill that provides $8.4 billion for military construction and family housing in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The package is $764 million less than what Bush sought. In a step certain to rile the president, the bill bars spending any federal funds from the NATO Infrastructure Fund for building a base in Crotone, Italy, for the Air Force's 401st Tactical Wing. The bill slashes the administration's request for the NATO Infrastructure Fund from $420 million to $193 million. Spain has said the wing of 72 F-16 jet fighters must be moved from Torrejon de Ardoz, and Italy agreed two years ago to provide a new home under NATO auspices. Lawmakers have questioned the wisdom of constructing a base in Europe when Cheney plans to close others overseas and at home.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Family Flies to France; Lebanon Denies Soldiers Massacred
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with plane arriving in France. Pickup 7th graf `An earlier...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's family late Friday flew to exile in France as a dispute between the French government and Lebanese intensified over the fate of the defeated rebel general. A small French government jet landed in France before dawn Saturday, carrying Aoun's wife, Nadia, and their three daughters, Mireille, 22, Claudine, 19, and Chantal. Aoun has been holed up in the French Embassy since last Saturday, when his 11-month mutiny was crushed by Syrian-led forces in a blitz that left at least 350 people dead. The Lebanese government has refused to allow Aoun and his aides to leave, and is insisting the general face justice for crimes including the theft of at least $75 million from the state treasury. Also aboard the jet were the wives of two senior aides to Aoun, Brig. Gen. Isam Abu Jamra and Col. Adel Sassine. They were accompanied by Abu Jamra's four children and Sassine's two boys, Beirut airport officials said. The French news agency Agence France-Presse, quoting an informed source, said the Mystere-20 jet landed at a military airport in France but that the location was not disclosed for security reasons. The plane's departure from Beirut was delayed more than five hours after Lebanese customs officials confiscated $200,000 cash from the bags of the three women, the officials said. An earlier Defense Ministry communique said Mrs. Abu Jamra alone was stripped of $150,000. The ministry communique said policemen combed the luggage, ignoring the protests of French Ambassador Rene Ala, who accompanied the women and children from the French embassy to the airport. The 12 dependents emerged from the French embassy Friday night in a 10-vehicle convoy. They drove from the eastern suburb of Hazmiyeh to the airport at full speed, passing through several Lebanese and Syrian army checkpoints that made no attempt to stop them. Aoun, Abu Jamra, Sassine and a third officer, Maj. Gen. Edgar Maalouf stayed at the embassy where they sought refuge on Saturday after their rebellion was crushed in a crackdown by Lebanese and Syrian troops. France has granted the officers and their families asylum. Also Friday, the Lebanese government angrily denied French reports that scores of Aoun's followers were massacred after they surrendered. Prime Minister Salim Hoss described the reports as ``allegations based on biased rumors,'' and the Defense Ministry said in a communique that the account was ``absolutely baseless.'' Witnesses said Aoun's wife and three daughters left the French Embassy in a convoy of embassy cars escorted by Lebanese military police. Two Air France jets had arrived in Beirut earlier. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said it was trying to obtain independent confirmation of reports that up to 100 of Aoun's troops were executed, but said it also wanted United Nations action. In a statement, the ministry called on U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to intervene, saying the reported atrocities ``aroused extreme emotion'' in France. Roman Catholic leaders in France pleaded with the government Friday to aid Lebanon's Christians. Cardinal Albert Decourtnay, president of the national conference of Catholic bishops, said Lebanon ``is experiencing the most tragic hours of its history.'' The Lebanese Defense Ministry communique said Aoun's slain troops ``fell in the military operation'' and there was no post-surrender massacre. When police examined the bodies at the Baabda government hospital's morgue, ``we found no solid evidence that the soldiers were liquidated,'' a police spokesman said Thursday. ``None of the corpses we examined had hands tied behind the back and very few of the dead soldiers were hit in the skulls with bullets,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. President Elias Hrawi accused Aoun of ordering his troops to continue fighting on Saturday even after he broadcast a message of surrender. The eight-hour air and ground assault by Syrian and Lebanese troops left 350 people dead and 1,200 wounded, by police count. According to police, the fatalities included at least 100 Syrian soldiers. Hrawi claimed that Aoun told his forces in a radio message: ``I'm in the French embassy. The outcome (of the battle) will be favorable to us. Go on. Go on fighting.'' ``These were the orders Aoun radioed to his forces, even after his message of surrender was broadcast,'' the presidential press office quoted Hrawi as saying. Military sources described ``ferocious hand-to-hand fighting'' on the eastern edge of the area Aoun had controlled. One source said that after Aoun's surrender, one of his commanders told the Syrians his troops were giving up - then opened fire when the Syrians came forward. ``Syrian infantrymen came out of their trenches to open terrain and were advancing slowly toward Aoun's lines to take over without shooting,'' the source said. ``Aoun's troops remained behind their barricades and opened up at the exposed forces with howitzers, mortars and machine guns, killing most of them, if not all,'' the source added. The Syrians then overran the position, the source said. Hrawi plans to form a government of reconciliation to unify divided Beirut and implement a peace accord to end the 15-year-old civil war and give Moslems and Christians equal power. Aoun rejected the peace accord, largely because it did not set a timetable for withdrawing Syrian forces. Syria, the main powerbroker in Lebanon, has had troops in the country since 1976. The Syrians are considered an army of occupation by many Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Shore Leave is Tame for Americans in the Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shore leave for U.S. sailors in the gulf has taken on a wholesome connotation that is a world away from the fleshpots of earlier military deployments. ``Bangkok it isn't,'' said a sailor downing a beer at an Oktoberfest party hosted for about 500 men and women recently in Bahrain. ``But it's better than nothing.'' Crew-cut Americans are a common sight now, jogging along the streets in Manama or buying up presents at the local gold market. Armed service personnel stationed in Bahrain do not face the same time-off restrictions as their counterparts do in Saudi Arabia, where at least 200,000 U.S. military are dug in against Iraqi troops who invaded Kuwait Aug.2. Bahrain offers alcohol, discos and beaches. Recreation under the rigid moral code of Saudi Arabia is more in the nature of tame videos and board games. Bahrain's Ministry of Information prepared a short videotape for military circulation on the island's culture and society. Sailors are given briefings on acceptable behavior before their liberty leaves in Manama. Arab women, for the most part, are off-limits. But drinking isn't and neither is shopping in the souk, the local bazaar. ``We were told not to stare at local women who are covered with face veils, but I found them more often staring at me. They look scary,'' said Seaman Brian Zaisa, 20, of Burlington, Iowa. Zaisa was standing night watch atop the bridge of the USS Blue Ridge, flagship of the 7th Fleet. He spends his days off bicycling throughout the small Gulf island-nation. The American Support Unit has operated for years as part of the commercial facilities that Bahrain extends to U.S. Navy warships in the region. Since the gulf crisis started the unit has held some parties for naval personnel. ``It doesn't take much to make Americans happy,'' an Air Force officer said on condition of anonymity. ``Often it's just music, a dance floor and beer.'' The U.S. military command in Saudi Arabia has been eyeing Bahrain and the bustling gulf port of Dubai as potential leave locations. But, as a .S. Air Force officer recently said in Bahrain, ``We wouldn't want to flood this little island with an excess of military personnel on R and R. It wouldn't be fair to the country.'' Bahrain is smaller than New York City and has a population of about half a million. Dubai, another tiny gulf republic, has also announced plans to expand its facilities for visitors - including building a new golf course. There haven't been any reports of disorderly conduct or crime by American soliders in Bahrain, a U.S. military source said. ``If anything, we have had small scraps between sailors off different ships, and marines or army, more than between the military and locals,'' said Mark Neuhart, commander of the Blue Ridge. Asked whether the U.S. military presence will affect Bahrain's Arab culture, Neuhart said: ``I believe this society will more likely have an effect on the men.'' Many sailors already have bought the traditional white robes, or thobes, and headgear, or gutras, that Arab males wear. ``They're popular because they're different and authentic. They'll probably wear them for Halloween,'' Neuhart said.

DOC.HEAD: Annunzio Got Money from Heads of S&L He Helped with Charter
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., wrote to a top federal regulator on behalf of three New York investors and later accepted campaign contributions from two of them, government documents show. Annunzio wrote letters in late 1984 to Edwin Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, about the investors' request to establish First City Federal Savings Bank in New York. The request, by First City principals Richard Greenberg, Frederick Greenberg and Dan Quigley, was approved by the bank board in January 1985. The two Greenbergs, who are brothers, each contributed $1,000 to the Chicago congressman's campaign fund in September 1985, according to Federal Election Commission records. Frederick Greenberg gave Annunzio another $1,000 in November 1987. Annunzio did not return three telephone calls to his office on Friday. A spokesman, Tom Seppy, said the congressman was not available. The 75-year-old Annunzio, a member of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee, has been under attack for his other S&L dealings in the first vigorous reelection challenge he has faced in years. The National Journal reported recently that officials of Standard Federal Savings Bank, a Maryland S&L threatened with federal regulatory problems, contributed $12,000 to Annunzio - who later championed their cause in opposing the rule. In his Sept. 20, 1984, letter to Gray, Annunzio said the three First City investors were ``most anxious to secure a charter as promptly as possible consistent with the regulations.'' ``Consequently, I would be deeply grateful if you would lookinto this matter and furnish me a report on the current status of the application as well as advise me when you anticipate final action will be taken,'' he said. Annunzio followed up with a second letter to Gray on Nov. 15, asking him to ``look into this matter once again and furnish me a current status report.'' The phone number listed for First City was disconnected and the principals also did not return calls. Gray was not immediately available for comment, a secretary in his office said. Annunzio has accepted more than $50,000 in campaign contributions tied to S&Ls over the last decade but has denied any conflicts of interest. Annunzio also has come under fire for reports that two of his sons-in-law once worked for the thrift industry's chief lobbying group, the U.S. League of Savings Institutions. He does acknowledge he once tried to get one of them a position with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Chicago but maintains there was nothing improper about the request.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Cuts El Salvador Aid, Agrees To Forgive Egypt Debt
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, its members weary of a decade of rangling over U.S. policy toward El Salvador, is endorsing a sharp drop in military aid to the country, marking a defeat for President Bush. Senators voted late Friday to cut El Salvador's $85 million in annual military aid in half, and set conditions on the remaining aid designed to encourage both the government and the country's leftist rebels to reach a negotiated peace. But at the same time, Bush was able to salvage a victory in the $15.5 billion foreign aid bill when senators voted 55-42 to forgive $6.7 billion in military debts Egypt owes the United States. Administration officials had portrayed the debt forgiveness as a reward to Egypt that is crucial to preserving an Arab consensus in support of the U.S. troop deployment in the Persian Gulf. The Senate adjourned for the weekend without finishing work on the foreign aid measure after it hit a snag over whether to reverse a five-year ban on U.S. aid to international population agencies that advocate abortion. On the El Salvador issue, the Senate first voted 74-25 for an amendment by Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., calling for an immediate 50 percent withholding of El Salvador's fiscal 1991 military aid. Under the amendment, if the country's leftist FMLN rebels walk away from U.N.-sponsored peace talks the aid could be restored. But if the government abandons peace efforts, what's left of the military aid could be cut as well. ``People are just fed up with this thing,'' Dodd said, referring to the millions of dollars in U.S. aid sent to El Salvador over the past decade. Other senators also expressed a weariness over the issue. The conditions in the Senate foreign aid bill are similar to those contained in a House-passed version. The two bills still have to be reconciled by a House-Senate conference committee, but the El Salvador provisions are expected to be in the final version sent to President Bush. Top administration officials and even Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani had been calling senators asking them to vote for the aide package, and the size of the defeat took administration backers by surprise. ``It was like a wave,'' said one administration official, adding that the tide seemed to turn after Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., who had been a supporter, voted the other way. United Nations-sponsored talks aimed at a cease-fire between rebel and government troops have been stalled over the question of military reform. The rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front claim the government has been intransigent about dismissing officers linked to human rights violations. Under the Caracas agreement, such political agreements must be worked out before a cease-fire takes effect. An estimated 70,000 people have been killed in the Salvadoran civil war; many of the deaths have been blamed on right-wing death squads operating in cooperation with the military. Several military officials have been charged in the murders last year of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. The overall foreign aid bill provides economic and military support for U.S. friends and allies around the world in the coming year. As usual, Israel gets the lion's share of the money - $1.8 billion in military aid and $1.2 billion in economic aid, along with an assortment of provisions providing other economic benefits. Other large earmarks are for Egypt, $2.1 billion; Morocco, $72 million; Greece, $382 million; and Turkey, $545 million. For the first time in years, there is no earmark for Pakistan, which historically has been among the largest aid recipients but now faces a cutoff because of apparent violation of nuclear non-proliferation requirements.

DOC.HEAD: 134 New AIDS Cases Reported in China
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese man died of AIDS recently and 134 new cases have been discovered, almost all among intravenous drug users, a health official says. The disclosure indicates that China, thought to face little risk of an AIDS epidemic because comparatively few Chinese inject drugs or are sexually promiscuous, is facing a serious health threat. A total of 378 Chinese have tested positive for the AIDS virus, Dr. Qi Xiaoqiu, of the Epidemic Prevention Department of the Public Health Ministry. saod Friday. The figure includes four Chinese who have died from the immune-stripping disease. All but 10 of the 378 were from the southwest Chinese province of Yunnan, which borders the drug-producing Golden Triangle. Previous reports on Yunnan victims of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome said they were drug addicts who injected heroin. The Golden Triangle produces much of the world's heroin, and an increasing amount of the drug is shipped across southern China to Hong Kong and beyond. Also this year, 27 foreigners have tested positive for AIDS, for a total of 68 infected foreigners found in China since 1985, Qi said. China expels foreigners carrying the AIDS virus. The first Chinese to test HIV-positive were four hemophiliacs infected in 1985 by contaminated blood products from overseas. They were the only reported Chinese AIDS patients until last year, when health workers found 149 Chinese infected with the HIV virus, including 146 Yunnan drug users. Yunnan officials said in May that health workers were unsure how to treat the patients. A medical team including specialists of the World Health Organization was to go to Yunnan next month to help care for them, official reports said Friday. The most recent AIDS patient to die was a Beijing resident in his 50s who had traveled to several foreign countries, Qi said. He died in August, the Xinhua news agency said. It wasn't known how he contracted the disease. Chinese who have lived abroad for more than a year and foreigners who plan to live in China for a year or more are required to undergo a test for AIDS when they arrive in China. Officials also are attempting to test all drug users, prostitutes and Chinese whose work puts them in contact with foreigners. AIDS is spread most often through sexual contact; contaminated needles or syringes shared by drug abusers; infected blood or blood products; and from pregnant women to their offspring. The scientific name for the virus is human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Seafood Delicacy Makes Annual Debut
DOC.TEXT: Stone crab fans waited for the season's first catches of the Gulf of Mexico's top crustacean like wine lovers yearning for the year's first Beaujolais nouveau or New Englanders watching for leaves to turn color. ``It's sweet, it's delicious, it's flaky - it's a legal narcotic,'' said Ron Goldstein, executive vice president of the East Coast Fisheries market and restaurant, holding up the rich meat from one of the first crab claws available during the Oct. 15-to-May 15 season. ``That's why people get all excited.'' Maine has its lobster and Maryland its blue-claw crabs, but people here swear stone crabs taste better. Dick McDaniel, who runs seafood operations at Joe's Stone Crab in Miami Beach, said diet makes the difference. ``Blue crabs eat garbage meat - the rottener it is, the better,'' McDaniel explained. ``But stone crabs are very persnickety. They must eat the Rolls-Royce of baits: fresh fish heads.'' Joe's has been serving up the tasty critters since 1913 and now serves up a ton of cold claws each night - 400,000 pounds a year - at $24.95 for little more than a pound of meat. In the early days at Joe's - when Miami Beach was little more than a sandbar with a bathhouse - writer Damon Runyon once observed that a man could dip his foot in Biscayne Bay and come up with a crab hanging from each toe. Now stone crabs roam mostly along Florida's Gulf coast. About 300 professional crabbers work the waters from the Keys to Panama City, taking more than 2.5 million pounds of crab claws each season, according to the state Department of Natural Resources. The crabs aren't killed, though. Crabbers, hauling in hundreds of traps each day, remove a claw at a time from the crabs before tossing them back into the sea, where they regenerate their lost limbs in the off-season. ``We're taking something off a live animal without killing or destroying him. We're doing something right with the harvesting,'' McDaniel said. The claws are quickly hauled off the boats and boiled before being iced down. So eager was Monty's Stone Crab restaurant in Miami to start serving the claws this year that it hired a helicopter to fly them in from the Gulf on Monday night. Their competition used trucks to cross the Everglades and couldn't serve fresh claws until the next day. Tourism officials see the start of each season as a sign that the summer doldrums are ending. ``We're already getting phone calls. We can start to feel the quickening pace at just about the same time stone crabs debut,'' said Mary Louise English, spokeswoman for the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau. Not all people see the start of stone crab season as a glorious event, however. For Sheri Ashcraft, an admissions adviser at Barry University and a native Floridian, it's a sign that Miami's clogged roads are about to get even harder to navigate. ``It's like `Attack of the Rental Cars.' You see their tags and they're always right in front of you, going 10 mph,'' she joked. ``The restaurants are more full. People suddenly appear in snow-white skin, with the wild shorts and zinc oxide on their noses.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Penalty Foes Say Virginia Electric Chair Malfunctioned
DOC.TEXT: Death penalty opponents believe the state's electric chair malfunctioned in the execution of convicted murderer Wilbert Lee Evans. They said witnesses saw the man bleed profusely the moment he was electrocuted. But the state's corrections director, Edward W. Murray, on Friday rejected calls for an investigation of Wednesday night's electrocution. ``The man just simply had a nosebleed - it's as plain as that,'' Murray said. The Virginia Coalition on Jails and Prisons, the Virginia Association to Abolish the Death Penalty and the American Civil Liberties Union of Virginia urged an investigation in a letter Friday to Murray. ``According to witnesses ... there is a strong possibility that the electric chair malfunctioned and that Mr. Evans suffered,'' the letter said. One witness, the Rev. Russell A. Ford, said he saw corrections officers and state officials cringe, then heard Evans make a sizzling sound when the electric chair was turned on. ``Something unusual happened the night of the execution, I can assure you,'' said Ford, who has witnessed six executions. ``Everyone was aware of that who was present.'' But Murray said the witnesses ``don't have their facts straight.'' Corrections officials said the bleeding may have been caused by high blood pressure or Evans' nose jerking against his death mask. Evans' body showed no evidence of trauma, according to the state medical examiner's autopsy report. And Deputy Corrections Director Edward C. Morris, witnessing his sixth execution, said: ``He did not make a noise.'' Evans, 44, was put to death at the State Penitentiary for shooting an Alexandria sheriff's deputy with his own revolver during a 1981 escape attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Racket In China to Smuggle Black Bears for Food and Show
DOC.TEXT: Officials at an agency in charge of protecting wildlife in China have been trapping black bears and selling them to restaurants that use them to entertain guests, a Chinese newspaper reported today. Some restaurants also kill the bears and use them to make bear's paw soup, a Chinese reporter in Canton said. The story, dubbed ``the case of the black bear,'' began Sept. 6 when one of the animals escaped into a park on the outskirts of Canton, southern China's biggest city, the independent Ming Pao newspaper said. The bear was fleeing the swanky White Cloud Restaurant, which is near the park and is a favorite watering hole of Chinese officials. The restaurant had handcuffed the beast since August and used it to entertain guests. A posse of 300 armed officers used police dogs to search the park but the bear eluded them. A Chinese reporter contacted in Canton said the incident was not reported in the city's press, which remains under tight control by the Communist Party. The 110-pound bear appeared twice in a residential area near the park, Ming Pao said. On Sept. 18, it killed and ate a chicken and eight eggs on the balcony of one man's house. Authorities fired on the beast but it escaped. A week later, the bear resurfaced; authorities shot at it again but missed. Authorities then set a trap for the animal and at 5 a.m. last Saturday the bear fell into it. ``Even though the bear was caught, the case of the black bear incident set people thinking,'' Ming Pao said. An investigation disclosed that officials at the Canton Wildlife Protection Society smuggled the bear and eight others from a nearby town to Canton on Aug. 24, the newspaper said. Initially, it said, the corrupt officials kept the bears at a medical center run by the society. The beasts were farmed out to high-class restaurants, which used the animals to lure customers, the newspaper said. China's economy in the south has grown tremendously since Beijing opened to the West in the early 1980s. Corruption and conspicuous consumption now run rife in Canton. Decadent practices, like dancing bears, and exotic dishes - like bear's paw soup or snake and cat stir fry - are commonplace. After authorities caught the escaped bear, the Guangdong Province Wildlife Protection Agency stepped in, seized the other bears and housed them in the Guangzhou Zoo. Many of the bears could not walk or stand because they had been in chains since August. An official at the wildlife agency said smuggling bears was illegal under Chinese law and that the investigation was continuing, Ming Pao reported. The Chinese reporter, speaking on condition of anonymity, said other bears had been smuggled to Guangzhou over the past year and had been killed by restaurateurs. ``They were used for soup,'' he said. However, he said, most of the smuggled bears were used for entertainment because bear's paw soup is a northern delicacy, and not generally favored by southern Chinese.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Take to Streets To Protest Violence
DOC.TEXT: Colombians angered by a new wave of drug and terrorist violence swarmed into the streets by the thousands in the capital and other cities. Thousands of people waving white handkerchiefs, praying or chanting peace slogans on Friday filled the cities' main plazas on Peace Day. The day was called in part to show solidarity with eight Colombians kidnapped by the Medellin cocaine cartel. Seven journalists, including the daughter of a former president and the editor of the major Colombian newspaper El Tiempo, were kidnapped last month. The sister of an ambassador was also abducted. Officials say the notorious Medellin cocaine cartel kidnapped the eight to pressure the government into granting its members a pardon. Reports emerged Friday of new terrorist attacks and threats. Melida Gaviria, mother of President Cesar Gaviria, had to reinforce her security and leave her hometown of Pereira, apparently because of threats by drug traffickers, sources in the president's family said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Presidential press spokeswoman Pilar Calderon denied that account, saying Mrs. Gaviria traveled to Bogota for a vacation. Police said four more people were kidnapped in the previous 24 hours in Medellin, Colombia's second largest city. So far this year, 915 people have been abducted in Colombia by drug traffickers, left-wing guerrillas and other armed groups. The cartel has been blamed for killing at least 550 persons since August 1989, when the government began an anti-drug crackdown after traffickers assassinated leading presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan. A huge mural of Galan hung over Bogota's Plaza Bolivar on Friday as sirens, an army marching band and shouting demonstrators clamored for peace. On hand were government ministers and family members of the kidnapped journalists. Special noontime Masses were held throughout the country. Three students lit a Torch of Reconciliation to symbolize recent efforts to bring peace to this violence-sundered nation of 30 million people. The events were organized by former first lady Nidia Quintero de Balcazar and her Solidarity for Colombia Foundation. On Thursday, leftist guerrillas of the National Liberation Army, the ELN, bombed Colombia's main oil pipeline for the 19th time this year, once again forcing the flow of crude oil to be suspended, the state oil company Ecopetrol said. The pro-Cuban rebels are trying to force the government to reduce the presence of foreign oil companies. Four guerrillas and two soldiers died in the previous two days in fighting in the countryside between rebels and the army, a military report said. Unidentified gunmen killed Cesar Augusto Giraldo, president of a small town council in north central Colombia, also on Thursday, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Pandemonium Erupts Over Proposed `Latin Quarter' Name
DOC.TEXT: Pandemonium erupted at a City Council meeting during discussion of a plan to use the name Latin Quarter instead of Little Havana for city projects in the predominantly Cuban-American neighborhood. More than 300 people jammed council chambers Thursday night, waving small Cuban flags, wearing armbands and toting placards. Dozens of spectators called commissioners names such as ``traitors,'' ``Communists,'' ``ticks,'' ``pigs'' and ``dirt balls.'' One woman spat on Mayor Xavier Suarez, a Cuban American. ``He's going to have to explain to his children what he did today,'' said Carlos Lopez Caballero. ``He's a traitor to his birthplace.'' Six police officers locked arms for 35 minutes early in the meeting to protect commissioners from the hostile crowd. By the end of the session, the city's police chief and 30 officers, three on horseback, were at City Hall. Eventually, the crowd grew too large for the council chambers and spilled outside. ``Have I ever sat through a meeting like that? No. Do I ever want to sit through a meeting like that again? No,'' said J.L. Plummer, a commissioner for two decades. Commissioner Miriam Alonso, a Cuban American, had proposed dropping the name Latin Quarter from city projects in the 34-block Little Havana communithy.
