Latin Quarter, used officially since 1979, is a term used for a planned shopping arcade and a small design district. Alonso said the term Latin Quarter slights the contributions of Cuban Americans in developing Little Havana.

DOC.HEAD: Indonesia Pledges Financial Support for ANC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One Name For Suharto and Murdiono cq.
DOC.TEXT: President Suharto today pledged $10 million to support the African National Congress in its struggle to end apartheid in South Africa, a government official said. Suharto made the pledge at a meeting with ANC leader Nelson Mandela, who arrived Friday for a four-day visit. Murdiono, minister of the state secretariat, said Mandela told Suharto the money was needed to finance education programs and reduce unemployment among blacks. The Indonesian government also promised to provide technical assistance for South Africa when apartheid is dismantled, Murdiono said. Before a dinner party on Friday, Suharto honored Mandela with a state medal for his ``extraordinary struggle against apartheid.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall $3.01 A Barrel
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell to their lowest level in a month as demand dropped, reports indicated supplies had rebounded from Middle East crisis and an Iraqi official hinted that war is less likely. The contract for November delivery of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil, closed at $33.79 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down $3.01 from Thursday and $5.81 from a week ago. It was the lowest price since Sept. 20. Home heating oil registered the biggest move, with the contract for November delivery plunging 8.11 cents to settle at 88.40 cents a gallon. That's nearly 17 cents lower than a week ago. Demand for home heating oil and diesel fuel for the week ended Oct. 12 was off a steep 30 percent from year-ago levels, said Peter Beutel, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. Heating oil demand has been depressed by a very warm autumn, while consumers worried about a deepening recession seem to be driving less, curbing demand for gasoline, analysts said. Also helping depress prices were reports that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are pumping between 22 million and 23 million barrels of oil a day - enough to fully compensate for the crude shortfall created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Oil futures prices plummeted on the opening bell in reaction to comments Thursday in Amman, Jordan, by Iraqi Deputy Premier Taha Yassin Ramadan, who said the crisis had entered a ``phase of reassessment and reconsideration of positions.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``My struggle has paid off. I am ending the fast on recommendation by our national assemblymen.'' - Korean opposition leader Kim Dae-jung, ending a 13-day hunger strike after the ruling party agreed to early local government elections. --- ``If I were any one of the five, I would be going ballistic - it's just not fair.'' - Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., criticizing the slow pace of the Senate investigation into the relationship of five senators with former S&L executive Charles H. Keating Jr. --- ``It's true that many of us are a little heavier around the middle and losing hair. But we're still here.'' - Lauren Langman, 50, one of more than 1,000 activists and leftists attending a weekend meeting in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Is Bush Using ``Code'' Word in Speeches, Senate Aide Asks
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Clayborne Pell, D-R.I., doesn't want to hear anymore about speculation that President Bush might be inserting a secret code word into his Persian Gulf speeches. An aide to Pell raised the possibility after repeatedly listening to recordings of Bush speeches. When they were played backwards, there seemed to be a recurring reference to ``Simone'' - possibly a code of some sort, according to the aide, C.B. Scott Jones. Jones, 62, a former Naval intelligence officer, raised the issue in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. But Pell, who is facing a tough re-election fight, has rimanded Jones, and said the whole matter ``sounds wacky.'' ``We regret this episode occurred and now consider it over,'' said Bill Bryant, a spokesman for the senator. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said he had no knowledge of any code words in anybody's Persian Gulf speeches.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Guerrillas Report Intensified Government Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Forces of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government have intensified attacks on guerrilla positions nationwide, the communist Khmer Rouge guerrilla group says. The report over Khmer Rouge radio on Friday also claimed that Vietnam dispatched three divisions into the country. The report came with peace talks still deadlocked by a quarrel over leadership of a national reconciliation body that the government and a coalition of three guerrilla groups formed in September. Often during the nearly 12-year-old civil war, each side has stepped up fighting to force political concessions. The Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge is the largest group in the guerrilla coalition. It also includes the U.S.-supported forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The guerrilla broadcast monitored in Bangkok said that since September, government forces have ``successively launched military activities on every battlefield throughout the country.'' It said they were concentrating on the northwestern province of Battambang, on the eastern province of Kompong Cham and on the central province of Kompong Thom. Vietnam sent two divisions to Battambang to defend the railroad, major roads and to retake Pailin, a rich gem-mining town, the guerrilla report said. The Khmer Rouge seized the town in September 1989 shortly after Vietnam said it had pulled the last of it troops out of Cambodia. The broadcast said members of the other Vietnamese division were spread out in various battlefields. The guerrillas maintain their major bases along the Thai border but have made significant inroads in Cambodia's central and northern regions this past year. Claims by both the guerrillas and the government are treated carefully by Western analysts since many are exaggerated. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people when its fanatical communist leaders ruled Cambodia by terror and famine in the 1970s. The group was ousted from Phnom Penh by the Vietnamese invasion of late 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Hold the Jalapeno, Inmate is Told
DOC.TEXT: A prison inmate got in a pickle by adding jalapeno peppers to a casserole she cooked for fellow inmates and prison staff. A disciplinary board at the Nebraska Center for Women sentenced Joy Anderson to 15 days confinement in her cell for violating a direct order - deviating from the casserole recipe - the inmate said Friday from the prison in York. Anderson, assigned to the kitchen staff, said she was cooking a Mexican-style hamburger-macaroni casserole for 150 people Oct. 8 when she tossed in four jalapeno peppers. Some of the inmates and staff liked the casserole. Some didn't. And they got angry - so angry that Ms. Anderson was placed in protective custody for her own safety. Of the discipline handed down Thursday, Ms. Anderson said, ``I think it's ridiculous, to tell you the truth. A verbal reprimand would have been sufficient.'' But Mary McNeill, the prison's assistant supervisor of administration, said the incident was a serious infraction. ``You don't mess with inmates' food,'' Mrs. McNeill said. ``Food is one of the major problems that can cause riots in prison,'' she said. ``Our standard policy is that all recipes are cooked according to recipe. This was not. And it caused a great disruption.''

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Takes A Breather
DOC.TEXT: Champion Garry Kasparov took one of his three allowed timeouts, postponing game 5 of his World Chess Championship series with Anatoly Karpov until Monday. The game had been scheduled for 5:30 p.m. Friday. Karpov used one of his timeouts a week earlier, after suffering a defeat in game 2. The other three games have ended in draws. Kasparov and Karpov are playing a 24-game series for the crown and a $3 million purse. The first 12 games will be in New York and the rest in Lyon, France. Kasparov dethroned Karpov in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Tries To Pressure Israel To Accept U.N. Investigators
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. chief says that if Israel proves intransigent, he may have no recourse but to report to the Security Council only on ways to protect Palestinians from Israeli buses. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Friday he will not send envoys to investigate the Oct. 8 police killing of at least 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem unless Israel decides to cooperate. ``The only thing on which I can report if my mission does not go to the area is on the protection and the safety of the Palestinians,'' he said. However, Perez de Cuellar gave the United States and other nations more time to try to persuade Israel to go along. Israel contends that letting in the U.N. investigation team would infringe on Israel's sovereignty in Jerusalem. He said he is not pursuing further efforts to win Israeli cooperation, but noted he believes ``some countries would like to exert some influence on the Israelis so that they end up by accepting the mission.'' The Security Council's president, British Ambassador Sir David Hannay, said the council will take up a statement or resolution Monday urging Israel to cooperate. Palestinian protesters threw rocks on Jews praying at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall. Security forces fired tear gas, rubber bullets and then live ammunition, killing at least 19 Palestinians and wounding 140. About 30 Israeli police and civilians were injured in the incident. On Oct. 12, the Security Council unanimously condemned Israel's security forces over the incident. The resolution - one of the few anti-Israel measures backed by the United States - expressed regret that worshipers were injured in its only reference critical of the Palestinians. The council requested the secretary-general to send a team to investigate the killings and report back by the end of October. Israel has said U.N. officials could enter as tourists, but the secretary-general has rejected travel on anything less than an official level. On Friday, Israeli troops shot and wounded at least 10 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip during a protest of the killings on Temple Mount, known as Haram es-Sharif in Arabic, one of the holiest sites in both Islam and Judaism. Palestinians said the Oct. 8 stoning began when rumors spread that Jewish zealots planned to march on the Temple Mount, whichis under Moslem control.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 80 Percent Of Vietnam Agencies Involved In Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Smuggling is so widespread in Vietnam that authorities estimate up to 80 percent of state agencies use their connections for black market profits. Everything from cars to cosmetics, beer to bras are smuggled into Vietnam, the government's Radio Hanoi said. It said smuggling ``has greatly jeopardized the economy and disturbed social order'' by robbing the government of taxes and hard currency and forcing local products to compete with foreign goods. The reform-minded adminstration of Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh has tried to strengthen the economy and purge many corrupt and incompetent officials. The radio report said that of 97 government-run facilities inspected, all but about 10 had used their official ties to smuggle items or buy them on the black market. In Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, at least 3,000 cases of smuggling have been detected this year, it said. Radio Hanoi said that ``whoever has the right connections'' has ``irresponsibly competed to import contraband in every possible way.'' ``It has been estimated that 80 to 90 percent of the hundreds of thousands of imported foreign goods on the market now are not essential to the laboring people's present life,'' said the broadcast, a transcript of which was seen Friday in Bangkok. Previous Vietnamese media reports said goods are smuggled from Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, China and other countries. In Vietnam's largest fraud trial, the manager of a perfume factory confessed the company lost $6.18 million since last year and intended to declare bankruptcy, Radio Hanoi reported. Nguyen Van Moi Hai, manager of the Thanh Huong Perfume Factory, made the admission Wednesday, the second day of the trial. When the trial began, thousands of people gathered near the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court to follow the proceedings on radio and television. Hundreds of demonstrators earlier this year demanded their money returned from an investment scheme using Hai's factory as a front. The state radio also said that after Hai confessed, three of the 21 other defendants in the case also admitted guilt. An earlier Radio Hanoi report called it ``the biggest case of fraud known to date,'' involving more than $28 million collected from hundreds of thousands of people during 14 months. Hai bribed government officials with sums of gold and cash, the court said.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Truckers End Strike That Caused $500 Million in Losses
DOC.TEXT: Independent truckers angered by higher fuel costs have ended an 11-day strike that forced factory shutdowns, disrupted food shipments and caused $500 million in losses to the French and Spanish economies. Luis Soldevilla, who negotiated with the government on behalf of the estimated 8,000 striking truckers, announced the decision Friday at the end of an eight-hour meeting with Transport Ministry officials. The government, which sets hauling rates, agreed to the establishment of a sliding rate scale to increase as the price of fuel goes up. It also agreed to increase government benefits for the self-employed owner-operators. The strikers dropped a demand that the government pay for damage done to their trucks by police trying to clear vehicles blocking the major crossing points between Spain and France. The strike began Oct. 9 over higher fuel prices and demands for early retirement and pension plans, officially acknowledged occupational illnesses and funds to compensate for them. Diesel fuel prices have risen 24 percent to $2.81 a gallon since the Persian Gulf crisis began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The walkout forced the shutdown of auto assembly plants in Spain and France as spare parts remained in stranded trucks or loading docks. Steel, paper and electrical appliance factories also were hit hard. More than 80 percent of Spanish goods are transported by truck, and 60 percent of Spain's truckers are independent. Transport Ministry officials had refused to negotiate with the truckers until they agreed Wednesday to remove their pickets from border areas and urban wholesale markets. Juan Jimenez Aguilar, secretary general of the Spanish Federation of Business Organizations, on Friday estimated the losses from the strike at considerably more than $500 million. He said the organization had sent an urgent letter to Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez asking him to avert the collapse of the economy. In Paris, Citroen announced it would lay off 15,200 workers at three auto assembly plants for at leat two days next week because the border blockades had disrupted deliveries of components. On Wednesday, the government-run automaker Renault announced the temporary layoffs of 22,000 workers because of the truckers' strike. Spanish civil guards cleared picketers from the three French border crossings late Wednesday. But French truckers mounted their own protests Thursday evening to protest their economic losses, Spanish National Radio reported. French police in Bayonne said about 2,200 trucks were still parked along highways in southern France waiting to haul their goods into Spain and Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Journalists Charge Government Trying to Take Over Opposition Paper
DOC.TEXT: Romanian journalists charge that the government is trying to muzzle the press by keeping it under state control. A front-page statement Friday by the Journalists' Union in the mass-circulation Tineretul Liber daily charged that ``some members of the government are attempting to subordinate the independent press to (the government's) own interests.'' It called on the government to reverse an Oct. 10 decision making the newspaper and some 30 other publications part of the state-owned National Publishing House. Tineretul Liber's editorial board maintains the staff should be given de facto collective ownership, since the paper has run itself and paid salaries from profits. After meeting editors of several papers, media minister Adrian Sirbu said Friday the government's position would not change. He accused the journalists of trying to steal state property. State-run TV has declared its support for the journalists. TV news director Victor Ionescu urged the government ``to stay out of matters which are not its business.'' Tineretul Liber, like most other dailies in Bucharest, uses state-owned publishing and printing facilities formerly used by the Communist-run press. Before the December revolution that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu's Communist dictatorship, Tineretul Liber was the Communist Party's official youth paper, though published under a different name. Since the revolution, the paper has often been highly critical of the National Salvation Front government. The Front led the movement against Ceausescu and then won the May elections. Many of its members are former Communist functionaries. Under the Oct. 10 decision, the 350,000-circulation paper is considered a state-administered company, although private bids for the paper - including by its staff - would be accepted after a planned privatization law is passed.

DOC.HEAD: Husband, Wife Sentenced in Cult Case
DOC.TEXT: Two members of a religious cult linked to the killing of a family avoided prison terms for their roles in helping to conceal the slayings. Dennis Patrick and his wife, Tonya, each were sentenced Friday in separate courtrooms of Lake County Common Pleas Court to 18 months in prison, 90 days in jail and one year probation. But the prison sentences were suspended and they got credit for the jail time because each had already served 93 days. Judge James W. Jackson said Patrick, his wife and their 10-year-old daughter, Molly, must continue receiving counseling. Mrs. Patrick told Judge Martin O. Parks she had been afraid to notify authorities about the slayings of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters on April 17, 1989, because cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren told her he would kill her daughter if she did not cooperate. Investigators had said Lundgren, who admitted to shooting the Averys, at one time also had intended to kill the Patricks. The Patricks said they still feared Lundgren, who was sentenced to death last month. The couple pleaded guilty last month to one count each of obstruction of justice for not disclosing the killings to FBI agents who came to the farm the day after the killings.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Day Election Begins; Boats, Helicopters Shuttle Voters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that first results expected Sunday sted Monday, SUB 3rd graf, `Polls open...' Pickup 4th graf, `At stake...'
DOC.TEXT: Voters in remote areas of Borneo were the first to cast their ballots in a two-day election that began today, with boats and helicopters transporting many people to the polls. About 200,000 voters were eligible in outlying areas of Sabah and Sarawak states, across the South China Sea from peninsular Malaysia. They got a head start because of the great distances and difficult travel involved. Polls open Sunday for the remaining 7.7 million eligible voters elsewhere in the country. First results are expected Sunday and full tallies early Monday. At stake are 180 seats in the federal Parliament and control of 11 of the 13 state legislatures. Sabah and Sarawak voted only for federal candidates. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's powerful National Front coalition was generally favored to win another term. It controls major portions of the media and dispenses much patronage. Some polling places deep in the Borneo jungle were accessible only by helicopter or boat. Officials in Sarawak said 16 helicopters and more than 1,000 river craft were at the service of voters. The state is half the size of France and 70 percent of it is jungle. The smallest polling station in Sarawak had six names on its register. Traditional longhouses, home to headhunters generations ago, were among the buildings used for voting. Security was tight. Paramilitary members of the Police Field Force were on patrol in combat uniforms. No outdoor rallies or political processions have been permitted in Malaysia since race riots after the 1969 elections left hundreds dead in the streets of Kuala Lumpur. Mahathir, 64, has been prime minister since 1981. The 10 largely ethnically based parties in his coalition and its predecessor have held power since independence in 1957. Components of the National Front held 133 of the 177 seats in the recently dissolved Parliament. Mahathir says he expects to win the two-thirds' majority necessary to amend the constitution. An opposition alliance led by former Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah is the first serious challenge to the governing coalition in eight elections since independence. Razaleigh, 53, narrowly missed in an attempt to topple Mahathir from leadership of the key United Malays National Organization in 1987. As the keystone of the National Front coalition, the group is the political voice of the Malay majority in this nation of 17.8 million people. There are sizeable Chinese and Indian minorities. No major national issues are being tested in what is largely a battle of personalities between two bitter rivals. The results from Sabah and Sarawak are awaited with great interest. The two states together control 47 seats and their politicians sometimes express disaffection with the leadership in Kuala Lumpur. The Sabah United Party, which is led by Christians in a nation with Islam as the official religion, pulled out of the National Front on Monday. Such defections are not unusual in Malaysian politics, but Mahathir denounced it as a ``stab in the back.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Tells Noriega's Lawyers to Get Case Moving
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's defense team must be ready to bring his drug-trafficking case to trial soon or the ousted Panamanian leader could be looking for new lawyers, a federal judge said. ``I'm going to have to set a date, and say you're in or you're out,'' U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler warned lead defense attorney Frank Rubino on Friday. Noriega's trial is scheduled to begin Jan. 28, but wrangling over legal fees, the threat of a new indictment, a pending civil lawsuit and the fate of Noriega's 15 co-defendants have bogged it down. Hoeveler acknowledged he may have to delay the proceedings. Meanwhile, the New York newspaper Newsday reported Friday that Noriega has made coded telephone calls through Rubino's office to contacts in Panama attempting to organize the overthrow of President Guillermo Endara. Quoting sources it did not identify, Newsday said U.S. investigators have broken the code used in the phone calls and turned the transcripts over to Panamanian authorities. But Panamanian Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon said he was unaware that the calls were encoded to hide a plot for insurrection. ``I have no information at all about that,'' Arias Calderon, who oversees Panamanian security forces, told The Miami Herald in a story published today. ``I was told about the calls, but it is the first time I hear that they were coded. No one briefed us on that.'' Rubino said he does not know the content of Noriega's telephone conversations, which are monitored by the government as are the calls of other prisoners. The lawyer said lack of money has kept him from beginning the investigative phase of Noriega's defense. He said all of the former leader's foreign bank accounts remain frozen despite a June agreement with the United States to release about $6 million. He told Hoeveler he fears a civil lawsuit the government of Panama is expected to file against Noriega in Miami next week could continue to tie up the money. The lawsuit is expected to accuse Noriega of looting his homeland and torturing and killing Panamanian citizens. Sam Burstyn, attorney for former Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid, accused the government of deliberately delaying the trial to try to force Noriega into a plea bargain. ``I don't think the government ever intends to prosecute Noriega, and my client is being held hostage,'' he said. In a motion demanding del Cid be released on bond, Burstyn said all sides are waiting for a new indictment against Noriega. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, denied the government was stalling. She said prosecutors would be ready to go to trial Jan. 28. She refused to confirm a new indictment is in the works. In August prosecutors told a magistrate in the case of co-defendant Roberto Steiner that the charges were expected to be broadened. Burstyn estimated a new indictment could delay the trial up to 10 months. Noriega and the 15 others were indicted here in February 1988 for allegedly allowing Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel to ship drugs through Panama. A Tampa indictment also accuses the Panamanian leader of marijuana smuggling and money-laundering. Noriega surrendered to American authorities after U.S. troops invaded Panama to capture him in December 1989. He is being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami. He faces up to 145 years in prison if convicted on all counts.

DOC.HEAD: Cool Weather in the East; Clear Skies For Most of Country
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped into the 30s in the East early today and clear skies were over most of the country. A storm system that brought an inch of rain to Northern California on Thursday was expected to move east today, with snow expected in Colorado and Wyoming and showers expected in the central Plains and Great Lakes region. Perfect fall weather, brisk and sunny, was predicted for the East today, the highs in the 50s and 60s. The South was looking for sunshine and warm temperatures, with highs reacing the 80s. High pressure was expected to bring sunny skies to the West. Temperatures were expected to reach the 40s in the Rocky Mountain states, the 50s in the Northwest and Midwest, the 70s in Northern California and the 80s in the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 95 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovaks Helped Suppress 1956 Hungarian Revolution, Polish Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak security forces helped suppress the 1956 anti-Communist revolution in Hungary and unrest the same year in Poland, a former interior minister is quoted as saying. Rudolf Barak, who served as interior minister from 1953 to 1961, was quoted Friday by the military weekly Obrana Lidu as saying Czechoslovakia supplied men and weapons to help put down Eastern Europe's bloodiest revolution. Barak's remarks were the latest in a series of admissions by former officials in Warsaw Pact countries since the anti-Communist revolution swept Eastern Europe last year. The ex-officials acknowledge that their forces helped suppress popular uprisings in other nations in the Soviet bloc. The Soviet Union and the four other Warsaw Pact countries that invaded Czechoslovakia during its 1968 attempts to create ``socialism with a human face'' condemned their actions last year. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said sending tanks to crush the Prague Spring was ``a mistake.'' Soviet troops marched into Hungary in November 1956 to put down an anti-Communist uprising. Many of the revolt's leaders were subsequently executed. They have been posthumously rehabilitated in Hungary's democratization process of the past two years. ``We provided immediate help to the Hungarian and Polish securities,'' Barak said, adding that about 30 men went to each country. ``We were also organizing supplies of machine guns and other weapons.'' Excerpts of the interview were carried by Czechoslovakia's official news agency CTK. In Poland in 1956, workers in Poznan were suppressed during demonstrations against one-party rule and Soviet domination. A period of liberalization followed after anti-Stalinist Communists staged a bloodless coup. Barak was a member of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, and in 1960-62 he worked as the country's deputy premier. In 1962, he was sentenced to 15 years in jail for abusing the powers of public office and embezzlement. He was released in 1968. Barak said he was actually imprisoned because he had gotten hold of documents that showed then-President Antonin Novotny, Barak's main rival in the party, had been a paid agent of the Nazi secret police. Germany invaded Czechoslovakia and ruled the country during World War II. Novotny was general secretary of the Communist Party from 1953 to 1968 and president from 1957 to 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Says Syrians Were Massacred
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with government denial that Christians were executed, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister denied that Christian soldiers loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun were executed after surrendering during a crushing attack by Syrian and Lebanese forces, a newspaper reported today. Defense Minister Alfred Mansour also said 200 more Syrian soldiers were killed than earlier reported, according to the leftist newspaper As-Safir. In the first official version on the fighting between Syrian troops and Aoun's followers, Mansour said there was a ``double-massacre'' after Aoun ordered his troops to continue fighting even though he had broadcast his surrender. Syrian and Lebanese forces ended the general's 11-month mutiny last Saturday when they overran his former enclave. He remained in the French Embassy, where he sought asylum, but his wife and children flew into exile in France today. The government of President Elias Hrawi has refused to allow Aoun and his aides to leave, accusing the general of looting the treasury of $75 million. Aoun's wife and three daughters arrived in France today aboard a French government jet accompanied by the wives of Brig. Gen. Isam Abu Jamra and Col. Adel Sassine, two of Aoun's top aides, officials said. Abu Jamra and Sassine are in the French Embassy with Aoun. ``Aoun's troops were not executed,'' As-Safir quoted Mansour as saying. ``What happened is that after Aoun's surrender statement was broadcast, we ordered the advancing troops to stop shooting, but fighting continued.'' ``We knew later that Aoun had given orders to his forces to continue fighting for three hours, hoping for foreign pressures in his favor,'' Mansour said. ``The Syrian forces, unaware of Aoun's keep-fighting orders, were taken by surprise and lost 200 dead.'' ``When the rest of the force reached Aoun's positions, the second massacre took place,'' he said. ``The bodies at the government hospital in Baabda are Aoun's troops who were killed in the confrontation.'' Mansour's disclosure that 200 more Syrian soldiers were killed raised the overall toll from the eight-hour air-and-ground assault to 550 dead, including 300 Syrian soldiers, and 1,200 wounded. French and British press reports said about 100 Aoun's troops were executed after surrendering. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon with 40,000 troops deployed in most of the war-torn nation. It supports the government of President Elias Hrawi. Hrawi traveled to Syria today for summit talks with President Hafez Assad and other Syrian officials. Hrawi told Syrian television Wednesday night that ``We thank the Syrian army for each drop of blood it shed in Lebanon.'' France on Thursday asked U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to order an investigation into the alleged execution of Aoun's troops after they surrendered to the attacking forces. The French stand was criticized by Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, who said it ``hurts Lebanon,'' noting that reports of the alleged executions were based on ``biased rumors.'' Lebanon and France have been locked in a diplomatic quarrel over Aoun. France has granted Aoun and his family asylum along with a number of his military aides and their dependents. But Hrawi's government said Aoun and his military aides will not be allowed to leave and should face a court of law for a variety of crimes. The government has not officially charged Aoun with stealing money from the treasury. But officials say Aoun and his aides were collecting taxes, fees for public services and customs dues in his area of influence and depositing the money in local and foreign banks instead of in the central bank in Moslem West Beirut. After crushing Aoun's mutiny, Hrawi's government moved to dismantle Beirut's Green Line, which has been dividing the capital into Moslem and Christian sectors for more than 15 years. After reopening roads linking the city's two sectors, the government hopes to create a militia-free ``greater Beirut'' to include the capital and its immediate suburbs. The main obstacles that face implementation of the greater Beirut plan is the deployment of Christian, Shiite Moslem and Druse militias in parts of it. The greater Beirut plan is in line with the government's plan to implement an Arab League-brokered peace accord to end the nation's 15-year-old civil war, which has killed more than 150,000 people. The peace accord, ratified by Parliament in August, distributes power equally between Moslems and Christians. Aoun had rejected the peace accord and refused to recognize Hrawi, also a Christian, as head of state.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts Iran's Southeastern Kerman Province
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook Iran's southeastern Kerman province early today, but caused no damage or injuries, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The quake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale, according to the report, monitored in Nicosia. The temblor's epicenter was 500 miles southeast of Tehran. An earthquake measuring 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage and loss of life in populated areas. The Richter scale is a guage of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Iran is still cleaning up from a severe earthquake in northwest Iran in June that killed 40,000 people. That temblor measured 7.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Dover, N.H., House Fire Kills Three Children; Five People Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Flames raced through a two-story house early today, killing three children and critically burning a fourth, authorities said. Four adults were also injured and were taken to Wentworth-Douglass Hospital, said Fire Chief David F. Bibber. Two adults escaped the home uninjured, he said. The nature of the injuries to the adults was not immediately known. Two boys and one girl perished when they were trapped on the home's second floor, Bibber said. A fourth child, a girl, was taken to the Shriners Burns Institute in Boston with burns over 80 percent of her body, the chief said. He said reports indicated all of those in the house were members of the same family, but no identities were released. The children were described as pre-teens. The fire was reported at 1:20 a.m., and Bibber said it was brought under control 30 minutes later. The cause was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Troops Killed 100 Rebels in Jaffna
DOC.TEXT: Advancing government troops have killed more than 100 Tamil rebels in the northern Jaffna peninsula, according to a military report published Saturday. But a rebel leader said 15 militants and 50 soldiers died in fighting Tuesday through Friday. The military report claimed only 14 soldiers were killed and 145 were wounded in the operations to ``clear the perimeters'' around military camps. The military plans to continue the offensive, but did not elaborate on plans. Both sides regularly make conflicting claims about death tolls, which cannot be independently confirmed because of disruption in communcations with Jaffna, about 185 miles north of Colombo. The communique said troops recaptured five areas that were under rule of the Tamil separatists, who have fought since 1983 for a separate homeland in northern and the eastern areas on the island nation. They claim discrimination from the Sinhalese majority. The military communique said most of the casualties were inflicted by air force helicopter gunships and aircraft that straffed guerrilla vehicles. ``During the operations, the security forces recovered a large stock of anti-personnel mines, war-like equipment, medical items, food stocks, stretchers and a few automatic rifles,'' it said. Jaffna peninsula, the northernmost part of the island, is a rebel stronghold where most of the fighting has centered. The hostilities were only interrupted during a 13-month cease-fire that ended last August. More than 14,000 people have been killed in fighting. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese make up about 75 percent and control the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: British Tornado Jet Crashes in Northwest Saudi Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A British Tornado fighter jet crashed in northwestern Saudi Arabia, injuring the navigator, a British military spokesman said today. The spokesman said the plane hit an obstruction while coming in for a landing at an air base in Tabuk late Friday. The pilot and navigator ejected from the plane and the navigator broke his leg, said the spokesman, who could not be named according to standing regulations. The navigator is in stable condition, he said. The British military does not release the names of personnel injured in accidents. The spokesman would not say what the plane hit, or release details on what happened to it after it crashed. The Saudi military and the British military are investigating. Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Britain has dispatched four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors to the region. Two squadrons are based in Saudi Arabia, including the one at Tabuk.

DOC.HEAD: Another Embassy Falls in Kuwait City, U.S. Holds Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Heath leaving Amman for Baghdad, British warplane crashing in Saudi Arabia. TRIMS from bottom. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY9,10
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's nearly 2-month-old effort to starve diplomats out of Kuwait has claimed another embassy, leaving only the U.S., British and French compounds as the last Western holdouts besieged by Iraqi troops. Canada on Friday pulled out the remaining personnel from its embassy in Kuwait City, where diplomats have resorted to burning furniture for cooking stockpiled food and boiling swimming pool water for drinking. As the diplomats suffered on in Kuwait, the first signs of protest against the troop buildup in the Persian Gulf were emerging in the United States. Despite polls showing Americans overwhelmingly support the U.S. deployment of more than 200,000 soldiers in the gulf region, opponents of the buildup planned protests today in at least 15 major U.S. cities. Although Britain has been one of the staunchest supporters of the U.S.-led effort to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, a former British prime minister, Edward Heath, traveled to Baghdad today on a personal mission to negotiate the release of 70 elderly and ailing Britons held hostage by Iraqi authorities. Heath, 74, left Amman, Jordan, on a scheduled Iraqi Airways commercial flight for Baghdad and refused to discuss his mission with reporters. Despite the fact that little has changed in the standoff since Iraq invaded Kuwit on Aug. 2, oil prices on Friday slid to less than $34 a barrel - down $3. The skittish market reacted in part to hints that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may be willing to negotiate an end to the 12-week-old occupation of Kuwait. Prices have topped $40, double since the crisis began, posing inflationary and recessionary pressures on the U.S. and other economies. Iraq's deputy prime minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said on Thursday in Amman that peace talks could be in the offing. But in Washington, President Bush said he saw no chance for compromise in the Persian Gulf crisis, which began when Iraq seized Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money. Bush met with a Soviet envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, who said he agreed that the world should not relax its insistence on an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. About 430,000 Iraqi troops are deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. A U.N. embargo has forced Iraq to ration food, and Baghdad says it will begin rationing gasoline Tuesday to save on imported chemicals that are needed to refine oil and that are now in short supply. Three Canadian diplomats and two wives arrived in Baghdad on Friday night, tired but well, 10 hours after leaving Kuwait, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said in Ottawa. The five, led by charge d'affaires William Bowden, planned to stay with staff from the embassy in Baghdad. Clark said the embassy is not officially closed and that this did not mean Canada recognized Iraq's claim to Kuwait. The Canadian action occurred the same day a report was published in Iraqi newspapers saying all foreigners in Kuwait must register with local authorities before Nov. 5 or face a fine and punishment. Since Aug. 24 Iraqi forces have cut off electricity and water to foreign compounds in Kuwait, which Saddam claims as Iraq's 19th province. The Belgian and German embassies in Kuwait closed Oct. 12, and the Dutch, Italian and Polish embassies withdrew their last diplomats from Kuwait City the week before that. Although the British, French and U.S. embassies are believed to be the only Western compounds remaining open, most nations still recognize Kuwait as a separate nation. An unspecified number of non-Western embassies remain open. The U.S. Embassy maintains about 10 diplomats led by Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell. An unknown number of American private citizens also have taken refuge there. The American diplomats have been surviving mainly on canned food and the occasional loaf of bread carried in by local staff. About 600 Americans are stuck in Kuwait, some in hiding and several are reported to be desperately ill. Iraq has placed scores of Westerners at military installations as human shields to deter any attacks. In other developments: -A British fighter jet crashed in northwestern Saudi Arabia, injuring the navigator. A British military spokesman said the plane hit something while coming in for a landing at an air base in Tabuk late Friday. -U.S. military officials in Saudi Arabia said there had been 2,500 interceptions, 240 boardings and 11 ``diversions'' of commercial ships since the embargo against Baghdad was imposed. -The Pentagon also said Friday that it is shipping several hundred of its best tanks - the M1-A1 - from Europe to Saudi Arabia. The announcement did not give a specific number, but it appeared the total was 300 to 400 and would bring total U.S. tank strength to nearly 1,000. That compares with the 3,500 Iraqi tanks the Pentagon says are deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. -A Defense Department satellite to be carried into orbit next month on the space shuttle Atlantis will provide strategic and tactical reconnaissance information from the gulf region, says a report to be published Monday in Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine.

DOC.HEAD: American Working for Chevron Kidnapped in Angola
DOC.TEXT: Armed guerrillas have kidnapped a U.S. helicopter mechanic for a company contracted by Chevron Corp., officials said. The state ANGOP news agency, quoting military sources, said Brent Swan was abducted early Friday by separatist rebels. But no group had claimed responsibility for the kidnapping. According to a government official who spoke on condition of anonymity, Swan and an Angolan colleague were abducted as they drove to a heliport in Cabinda, an oil-rich province where rebels have staged anti-government operations. Gary Weber, a spokesman for Petroleum Helicopter Inc. in Lafayette, La., confirmed Swan is an employee, but declined to discuss the incident ``at this time.'' The Angolan official did not give Swan's age or hometown. It was not immediately possible to contact Cabinda Gulf, which contracts with Chevron in the southwest African nation to operate platforms in the Atlantic Ocean. Bonnie Chaikind, a spokeswoman at Chevron headquarters in San Francisco, had no further information about the report. Last month, two Portuguese aid workers were kidnapped by a Cabinda separatist group linked to U.S.-backed rebels fighting Angola's Marxist government. The Portuguese government said the Front for the Liberation of Cabinda Enclave was holding the two in Zaire. The front is linked to the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, which has been fighting the Soviet-backed government since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Cuban troops supporting the government have protected foreign oil installations from attack. Under a 1988 peace agreement, about 12,000 Cuban troops remaining in Angola are due to withdraw by mid-1991. On Wednesday, the House voted to preserve covert U.S. military support for UNITA. But lawmakers also provided that the aid could be suspended if Angola's government agrees to a cease-fire and schedules elections in which the UNITA rebels may participate.

DOC.HEAD: Confederate Widow Wants World to Know `I'm Still Here'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `I heard...', to DELETE reference to battle of Gettysburg, which happened in 1863.
DOC.TEXT: Reports that the last Confederate widow died last week surprised an Alabama woman who has evidence that her late husband also fought for the South in the Civil War. ``I'm still here,'' said 83-year-old Alberta Martin, who married Confederate veteran William Jasper Martin in December 1927. News reports, including those of The Associated Press, after the Oct. 13 death of Daisy Wilson Cave described the Sumter, S.C., woman as the last surviving Confederate widow. But Mrs. Martin said Friday she was 21 and working in a cotton mill when she and Martin were married at the Covington County Courthouse in south Alabama. She said her husband was about 80 when he died about five years later. Martin was with the 4th Alabama Infantry in 1864 and 1865, according to the records of his stepson, Harold Farrow of North Little Rock, Ark. Mildred Cook, president general of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, said Mrs. Martin is the lone surviving Confederate widow affiliated with her 25,000-member organization. She said there may be other Confederate widows, although she is not aware of any. Farrow's wife, Marilyn, said her mother-in-law may have been overlooked as a surviving Civil War widow because she does not draw a Confederate pension. After Martin died, Mrs. Martin married his grandson, Charlie Martin, which apparently made her ineligible for the pension. Mrs. Martin said she can barely remember her husband talking about his wartime experiences. ``I remember him talking about moving up through the field picking up potatoes,'' she said. ``He said they'd come across a patch of potatoes, anything they could come across'' to eat. Farrow recalled attending his stepfather's funeral when he was 7 and how he and his half brother, William had to relinquish medals the elder Martin had given them so they could be pinned on his burial clothes. ``We had cherished them very much,'' Farrow said. ``I remember crying at the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma Threatens Politically Active Buddhists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with soldiers surrounding monasteries. Pickup 12th graf, `Mandalay was...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers cordoned off Buddhist monasteries in Burma's second largest city today after the military government threatened to disband Buddhist organizations whose members are refusing to minister to soldiers. The government threat, carried on state radio, also said the offending Buddhists will be expelled from their orders because they have violated the rules of their religion by becoming politically involved. Thousands of Buddhist monks in Burma have stopped ministering to the soldiers to protest government crackdowns on pro-democracy protests. The action by the monks, who have been at the forefront of anti-government protests in Burma, is the equivalent to excommunicating the soldiers in this predominantly Buddhist country, a Western observer in Rangoon said today. The government announcement on Rangoon Radio said, ``Such illegal organizations will be dissolved ... from (midnight) tonight, and members of such illegal organizations are not eligible to be members of the Sangha.'' The Sangha is the main religious governing body in predominately Buddhist Burma. The government said ``such organizations ave jeopardized the peace and stability of the country and threatened the breakup of the central Sangha organization by various means, including threats, blackmail and boycott.'' The announcement was repeated throughout the day, interspersed with martial music. The Western observer said any move against members of the Sangha is ``bound to cause some kind of popular reaction.'' He spoke by telephone and, like other observers and sources who commented on the situation, requested anonymity. The groups singled out by the radio included the Young Monks' Organization in the central city of Mandalay. On Sept. 6, the organization announced a boycott of religious ceremonies for soldiers and their families after troops broke up an anti-government protest there on Aug. 8. During the demonstration troops killed four people, including two monks, according to Western diplomats in Rangoon. Burmese sources in Mandalay said today that soldiers began cordoning off monasteries there this morning. The sources said the soldiers were expected to search the monasteries after midnight. From Mandalay, the monks' protest involving ministering to the nation's soldiers spread west to the district of Monya and to some monasteries in the capital, Rangoon, 350 miles south of Mandalay. A second Western source said about 160 monasteries in the capital had taken up the protest and that it now involved 15,000 monks, or about one-quarter of the total in the city. However, it appeared the boycott was most widespread in Mandalay where there were some 20,000 monks, he said. Mandalay was a major center of unrest during the 1988 pro-democracy uprising. Monks led the protests and took over the administration of the city for several weeks that year. Leader Saw Maung's troops crushed the revolt in September 1988, and soldiers killed thousands of protesters. The military government held a national election May 27 that was easily won by the National League for Democracy, the nation's main opposition group. But the government refused to hand over power and arrested opposition leaders. The Western source doubted the government could single out those monks behind the current boycott because it has become so widespread. ``It will be like trying to catch quicksilver,'' he said. About 85 percent of Burma's 40 million people are Buddhist and some 300,000 monks live in monasteries around the country. In Buddhist societies, monks play an important role in popular celebrations and rites. In a meeting with 19 senior monks Thursday, the prime minister, Gen. Saw Maung, said the boycott must end by today. ``I have tolerated as much as I can,'' he said. ``The situation is very dangerous, both in terms of religion as well as in terms of the country and of the people. Normal measures are no longer sufficient to ensure the perpetuity of the religion.''

DOC.HEAD: North Korean Soldier Defects To South Korea
DOC.TEXT: A North Korean army sergeant defected to South Korea Saturday across the central portion of the Demilitarized Zone separating the two nations, the Defense Ministry announced. It identified the North Korean defector as Shin Gwang-ho, 24. Shin walked across the 2.5-mile wide DMZ and surrendered to a South Korean outpost near Hwachun, 60 miles northeast of Seoul, the ministry said. Military authorities were investigating his motives. Shin was the second North Korean soldier to defect to South Korea in a little more than a month. On Sept. 7, a North Korean army staff sergeant swam across a narrow channel and defected at a South Korean island off the west coast. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South in 1945. The border is one of the most heavily armed in the world, with more than 1.5 million troops deployed on both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Voters And Some Close Races For Senate, Governor
DOC.TEXT: An angry and unpredictable electorate is leaving politicians wary of Election Day surprises. Seven Senate races and 14 contests for governor are too close to call. The strongest Democratic prospects are in races for governor, according to a state-by-state analysis by The Associated Press. Republicans recruited strong Senate candidates and began this midterm election campaign with high hopes of trimming the Democratic majority. GOP gains now look less likely. Senior senators in both parties are in danger of losing. They are Republicans Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Mark Hatfield of Oregon, and Democrat Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island. The Democrats' best chances are in governor's races, in part because GOP governors in several key states are not seeking re-election. That boosted Democratic chances of electing governors in California, Texas, Illinois, and Oklahoma. In addition, six Republican governors face tough challenges, including embattled Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida. The stakes are particularly high in governors' races because of the role the winners will play next year when congressional and state legislative district lines are redrawn to conform to the 1990 Census results. California, Texas and Florida are expected to gain a total of 14 new U.S. House seats. Despite the volatility of the electorate, the House once again looks like a secure political haven with only a handful of members facing serious challenges. The big question this year is whether an anti-incumbent mood will surprise officeholders on Election Day. ``The mood is bad and getting worse,'' said Democratic pollster Geoff Garin. He cited the ``budget fiasco'' which he said ``confirms every worst suspicion people have about the political system.'' He predicted that ``some incumbents who've become complacent because of their easy elections in the '80s are going to end up out of work.'' ``There is no question people are very, very angry out there,'' said Michele Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors' Association. She cited the budget stalemate and said the public hears ``nothing but bad news. Something's broken and the people we paid to fix it are too busy fingerpointing to do the job.'' Voter anger struck in Massachusetts, where primary election voters rejected establishment politicians and nominated Democrat John Silber and Republican William Weld for governor. Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, made no secret of the fact he voted for George Bush over home state favorite Michael Dukakis in the 1988 presidential election. In New Jersey, voters are furious over Democratic Gov. James Florio's proposal to raise taxes $2.8 billion. Some of that anger is spilling over to hurt Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley. Still considered a safe bet to win a third term against a challenge by Republican Christine Todd Whitman, Bradley saw his approval ratings drop 8 points in a recent poll. The senator still led Whitman 56 percent to 26 percent. ``It appears the decline in support for Bradley is a result of voter frustration over taxes,'' said Janice Ballou, director of the poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute for the Newark Star-Ledger. For months, politicians were unable to compete with the Persian Gulf crisis for public attention. When people finally began to pay more attention to domestic politics, the issue that stood out above all others was the budget, an issue that entangled Congress for weeks with an outcome certain to result in higher taxes for everyone. Democrats control the Senate by a margin of 55 to 45. Twenty-nine of the nation's governors are Democrats and 21 are Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: are Republicans.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the closest races, starting with Senate contests: NORTH CAROLINA - Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, is giving Sen. Jesse Helms the toughest race of his career. Independent polls say the race is a dead heat. Gantt and Helms differ on just about every issue. The conservative Republican senator depicts his challenger as ``an extremist'' who supports late-term abortions and those for sex-selection. Gantt depicts Helms as an ideologue who votes against the interests of his state, particularly on education and the environment. IOWA - Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin is battling Rep. Tom Tauke as well as an Iowa tradition of not re-electing Democratic senators. Polls show Harkin consistently in the lead but his edge is often well within the margin of error. Abortion is a major issue with Harkin pro-choice and Tauke firmly opposed to abortion. Iowa bucked a national trend in the 1980s and became one of the strongest growth areas for the Democrats, a factor that could help Harkin in a close race. OREGON - Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield, bidding for a fifth term, may be the best example of a complacent incumbent. Democratic businessman Harry Lonsdale hammered away at Hatfield for months and the senator ignored the challenge until a recent poll showed Lonsdale had climbed to within 6 points of the incumbent. Another race in which abortion is an issue; Hatfield is opposed while Lonsdale is a supporter. HAWAII - Generally regarded as the best chance for the Republicans to pick up a Democratic seat. Democrat Daniel Akaka was appointed to the Senate last summer after Spark Matsunaga died. A lackluster campaigner who held a safe House seat for seven terms, Akaka is opposed by Republican Rep. Pat Saiki. Even Hawaii Democrats conceded that Saiki is a dynamic campaigner and has a strong chance to win in this heavily Democratic state. MASSACHUSETTS - Sen. John Kerry was considered a shoo-in for re-election in this heavily Democratic state until the voters expressed their rage in the Sept. 18 primary. Suddenly, independent polls said the race between Kerry and his Republican challenger, Jim Rappaport, was a dead heat. A wealthy businessman prepared to spend millions on the race, Rappaport is concentrating on linking Kerry to the highly unpopular outgoing governor, Dukakis. RHODE ISLAND - Democrat Claiborne Pell was elected to the Senate in 1960, the year John F. Kennedy was elected president. His six terms have given him the seniority to become chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee but have also made him vulnerable to a challenge from 43-year-old Rep. Claudine Schneider. Politely but firmly, Schneider suggests it is time for a younger person to take Pell's seat. However, recent polls give Pell, 71, an 18-point lead. NEW HAMPSHIRE - GOP Rep. Bob Smith was heavily favored to capture the Senate seat being vacated by fellow conservative Gordon Humphrey. But former Sen. John Durkin has made a race of it and a recent poll said Smith's 4-point lead was within the margin of error. In other states, a large number of Senate contests looked tempting to challengers but didn't seem to pan out. They include Illinois where Democratic Sen. Paul Simon looks far ahead of Republican Rep. Lynn Martin; Michigan where Democratic Sen. Carl Levin is outdistancing Rep. Bill Schuette; Nebraska where Democratic Sen. James Exon leads former Rep. Hal Daub; Kentucky where Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell leads Harvey Sloane, and Montana where Democratic Sen. Max Baucus is well ahead of Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad. Among the races for governor, these are getting the most attention: CALIFORNIA - The battle between former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee, and GOP Sen. Pete Wilson is generally regarded as the most important contest in the nation. California is likely to pick up seven new House seats in 1992 and if Feinstein wins her party will have total control of how the lines are drawn in the nation's most populous state. A victory for Wilson gives the GOP an important role although the legislature will remain Democratic. Wilson and Feinstein agree on more issues than they disagree. Wilson's lead in the polls is well within the margin of error. TEXAS - Republican millionaire Clayton Williams seemed well on his way to victory over Democrat Ann Richards. But last week a new poll said Richards had moved to within 5 points of Williams, whose repeated verbal gaffes may be cutting into his support. FLORIDA - Martinez got into trouble over taxes early in his first term and then found his hard-line anti-abortion stand had moved out of favor with voters. Former Sen. Lawton Chiles got into the race and led in most polls. Recently the margin has narrowed and Martinez has a big edge in money. Florida is one of the six states where GOP governors are threatened. The others are Alabama, where Gov. Guy Hunt is leading teachers union official Paul Hubbert; Nebraska, where Gov. Kay Orr is trailing businessman Ben Nelson; Kansas, where Gov. Mike Hayden and state treasurer Joan Finney were in a dead heat; Maine, where former Democratic Gov. Joseph Brennan held a narrow lead over Gov. John R. McKernan; and Rhode Island where Gov. Edward DiPrete was running far behind businessman Bruce Sundlun. The best bets for Republican pickups were in Vermont, Alaska, Massachusetts, Oregon, and Ohio. Democratic governors are not running in each of those states. In Oklahoma, GOP Gov. Henry Bellmon is not running and Democrats hope for another gain.

DOC.HEAD: Four Workers Killed As Buddhist Pagoda Collapses
DOC.TEXT: A Buddhist pagoda under construction collapsed, killing four workers, an official said. The workers were plastering the upper part of the 135-foot-high pagoda when it caved in Thursday in Thailand's northeastern province of Roi-et, provincial Gov. Suporn Supasorn said in a telephone interview. He said it took about 15 hours to retrieve the four bodies from the tons of debris. A fifth worker was injured. There are numerous pagodas throughout Thailand, a predominantly Buddhist nation.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill 10 Communist Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Government troops killed 10 Communist rebels in two clashes in the central Philippines, the military said Saturday. The latest incident took place Friday in La Castellana town on Negros island, about 340 miles southeast of Manila, said army regional commander Col. Jose Maria Solquillo. He said soldiers backed by militiamen while on combat patrol stumbled on a band of 50 New People's Army rebels who were resting in a sugarcane field. He said the government troops immediately fired on the rebels, touching off a 15-minute battle that left five insurgents dead. The rest of the rebels fled in different directions. It was the second clash between government troops and guerrillas in four days in Negros island, which is considered a hotbed of the 21-year-old communist insurgency. On Tuesday, soldiers killed five rebels in Moises Padilla town, just southeast of La Castellana.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Earthquake and Aftershock Hits Western China
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake hit northwest China Saturday afternoon, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. There were no immediate reports of casualties. The quake measured 6.2 on the Richter scale, and hit at 4:07 p.m. (4:07 a.m. EDT), the report said. It was followed 32 minutes later by another temblor measuring 5.1, Xinhua said. The quake's epicenter was near Gansu province's Tianzhu Tibetan Autonomous County. The area is about 750 miles west of Beijing. The report said strong aftershocks were felt as far as Lanzhou, about 125 miles northwest of the epicenter. A severe earthquake in April in neighboring Qinghai province killed 126 people. Aftershocks from that quake also were felt in Lanzhou. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion on a seismograph. An earthquake measuring 6 can cause extensive damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Police Arrest Students to Deter Protests
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have arrested five students, police said Saturday, in an apparent effort to stem anti-government protests that included a suicide that shocked the nation. The arrests were made after Tanawot Klingchue, 21, set himself ablaze outside Ramkhamhaeng University Oct. 13 after making a speech at a rally demanding that the government resign for alleged corruption. Tanawot died in a hospital on Thursday. His action, highly unusual in Thailand, stunned the public and renewed popular discontent with Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan's coalition government. A photograph of the student, his body covered with flames from his neck to his feet, was widely distributed in the United States. Police officer Vissanu Tuengsook said authorities on Thursday and Friday arrested the five Ramkhamhaeng University students, who had been out on bail since being arrested at a protest rally earlier this year. They were taken into custody again on the same charge - inciting public unrest. A sixth person, Nikom Kesorn, a member of the Revolutionary Council, also was arrested. The little-known Revolutionary Council first surfaced in 1987 to call for ``peaceful revolution.'' Vissanu said the six were not suspected of involvement in the most recent protests. They apparently were arrested to dampen the protest mood. Chatichai's 2-year-old administration has been widely criticized for alleged corruption and ineptitude and for internal bickering.

DOC.HEAD: New! Improved! Army Rushes Research To Improve Equipment for Saudi Troops
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: In Army jargon, it's a flameless ration heater. To the soldier in the Saudi desert, it's an easy way to turn lukewarm food in a plastic pouch into a hot meal - using cold water. The heaters weren't supposed to hit the production line for two years, but 5 million are being sent to Saudi Arabia in time for winter. They're among dozens of innovations developed by Army researchers that are being rushed from the drawing board into prdduction because of the deployment of American troops to the Middle East. The new products include better boots, revamped desert camouflage to replace the now-familiar ``chocolate chip'' fabric the troops are wearing and water recycling kits designed to cut by 40 percent the use of scarce water at the Army's huge field laundries. Some of the products now ready for Operation Desert Shield weren't even on the drawing board when President Bush sent U.S. troops to the region on Aug. 8. As the troops and weapons arrived, a military outfitted for a European war against the Soviets realized it lacked gear essential to surviving the harsh desert climate. So it called on the Army research labs here, where the designers of the equipment used by American troops stationed in Alaska and other cold-weather climates have been working overtime on products for the scorching desert. They are cutting months and in some cases years off routine schedules for product development, in the process providing lucrative work for defense contractors who stand to gain millions. ``In peacetime, we have a lot of testing and checks and balances,'' said Frank Kostka, who heads the division of the labs that designs tents and other outdoor protective gear. ``In a situation like this the system has to be extremely flexible. You get smart quickly when you have to.'' Kostka's crews at the research labs also have developed new solar covers that attach to the camouflage nets carried by tanks and other heavy equipment. The screens not only block out 80 percent of the sunlight but can resist chemical attack. The first covers are stacked in a huge production room at the Natick labs, waiting to be shipped to Saudi Arabia later this month. The Pentagon is spending $600,000 to have hundreds more produced commercially from the lab's design, and another $1 million on lighter sun covers designed to protect storage and maintenance areas far back from the front. In a softball field on the sprawling complex is another recent invention - a huge but lightweight tent to be used as a portable maintenance garage in the desert. The tent is big enough to house an M-1 tank and light enough to be moved by four men. Kostka briefed military planners last week on another new product: double-layered tents designed to serve as hospitals or command posts in chemical-contaminated environments. Because of the design, troops inside would be able to work in shirt sleeves instead of hot, bulky protective suits. In another office at the labs, Vasant K. Devarakonda is waiting like a salesman to show off the latest in desert footwear, a suede and nylon boot that matches the desert uniforms. A steel-plate in the soles of the Vietnam-era boot - designed to protect soldiers from pongee sticks - is removed from the new version because it would heat up the inside. Not that the boots won't get warm. ``Eventually, at 120 degrees everything is going to get hot,'' Devarakonda said with a shrug. Researchers also hope to begin testing another invention: a personal airconditioning unit carried on a backpack. One early prototype used an engine from a weed whacker to power a tiny blower unit that pumps cool air into a specially designed vest. That awkward-looking device weighed 22 pounds; the researchers believe a smaller, specially designed engine might bring the weight down to 15 pounds. Television footage of a soldier guzzling water from a plastic water bottle was the impetus for another invention - an insulated camouflage pouch that carries - and cools - bottled water. If the Pentagon agrees to pay about $4 apiece to produce them, the carriers would replace the current insulator of choice in the desert - a wet sock. Philip Brandler may have the toughest job at the labs: He's in charge of the food. It was Brandler's office that rushed into development the ration heaters, which uses a pad treated with iron, magnesium and salt to heat a meal to 180 degrees. There's also a new hot dog meal, pancake and waffle breakfasts and a turkey dinner that will be available to the troops on Thanksgiving - stuffing and cranberry sauce included. Still in the works are a new chili dish and dehydrated soda tablets. In developing those, which require only water to produce carbonated drinks, the researchers also discovered how to make a dehydrated drink that would be coveted in the Saudi desert - beer. Even though it's nonalcoholic, the inventors don't think the Pentagon will order any. But Brandler is promising to provide another treat. The Pentagon is negotiating with several companies, including Hershey, which is licensed to market a Swiss-patented chocolate that won't melt until the mercury passes 140 degrees. Mars has its own version, and has agreed to use it in M&Ms it currently provides for field rations. ``We think that will have a tremendous morale impact,'' Brandler said. ``They won't melt in your hand and they won't melt in the sand.''
