DOC.HEAD: Federal Study of Agent Orange Exposure Wasted Millions, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: The federal Centers for Disease Control misspent $6.6 million while conducting a disputed study of the effects of Agent Orange, according to a congressional study released Saturday. The General Accounting Office said the money was spent on work by outside contractors that was not needed or could not be carried out because CDC did not have a methodology ready to begin the work. Agent Orange was a herbicide sprayed by U.S. troops during the Vietnam War to remove jungle cover. Many veterans contend it is responsible for cancers, birth defects in their offspring and other ailments. The report fueled renewed criticism from congressional critics of the CDC's handling of the Agent Orange study ordered by Congress. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., chairman of the House human resources and intergovernmental relations subcommittee, called the report ``direct evidence that the political manipulation of the Agent Orange study resulted in the waste of millions of taxpayer dollars.'' GAO's investigation was conducted at the request of Weiss' subcommittee, which has jurisdiction over CDC. The panel charged in August that the Reagan White House covered up scientific evidence about Agent Orange. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said ``The suppression of this information, combined with the millions of taxpayers' dollars wasted in the process, makes this coverup by the White House and CDC a disgrace.'' The $6.6 million amounted to nearly 10 percent of the $70.4 million Congress appropriated for the study and 20 percent of the money spent for work by outside contractors. Congress in 1983 directed CDC to conduct a series of studies of the effects of Vietnam veterans' exposure to Agent Orange and its primary component, dioxin. The GAO, an investigative arm of Congress, said CDC awarded two major contracts for interviews and examinations of veterans before it had developed approved methods to accurately identify Agent Orange exposure using military personnel records. ``As a result, CDC was unable to have the contractors start work on the Agent Orange study and paid the contractors $6.6 million ... for down time it caused the contractors and for work that was not needed to do the studies,'' the GAO report said. CDC completed portions of its study but canceled a major one aimed at determining if there was a statistically significant relationship between exposure and veterans' health. It said it could not use military records to accurately determine exposure. The money was part of larger contracts CDC awarded to Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina and Lovelace Medical Center in New Mexico. The contracts were to interview veterans, conduct psychological reviews and do medical exams. A spokeswoman for the CDC in Atlanta, Gail Lloyd, said the agency had not seen the report and had no comment beyond what was included in it. The GAO report said CDC officials, who were not identified, defended the contracts and said they were not awarded prematurely. They said that at the outset in 1983, CDC stated that many of the proposed methods were untested, pilot study assessments were required, and a recommendation not to proceed might be necessary. The GAO responded that the CDC contracts should have included options to halt the work.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Dance Troupe Claims U.S. Tour Marred by Politics
DOC.TEXT: Threats and enticements to defect tarnished a Cambodian dance troupe's five-week U.S. tour, organizers said Saturday. The company is scheduled to return to Cambodia on Monday without five of its 36 members. Four performers defected and star dancer Yim Devi has a visa to remain in the United States until December. He reportedly hopes to stay in the country to study. The United States does not recognize Cambodia's Vietnamese-controlled government, although U.S. relations with Phnom Penh and Vietnam have improved recently. The troupe, the first Cambodian artists invited to the United States since 1971, performed 1,000-year-old classical dances in Los Angeles, Seattle, Washington D.C., New York and other cities. The performances earned good reviews, but organizers at a news conference in Bangkok Saturday said the tour was ``marred by attempts to politicize an artistic event.'' Ouk Socheath, a dean at Phnom Penh's University of Fine Arts, said the group was continually harassed by a few members of the Cambodian-American community, many of whom strongly support non-Communist rebels seeking to overthrow the government. The two main rebel groups are joined by the Communist Khmer Rouge, which brutalized the country during its rule from 1975-78 and all but wiped out traditional arts such as classical dance, characterized by sensual, fluid movements of the body and hands. John McAuliff and Eileen Blumenthal, U.S. organizers of part of the tour, said a small number of Cambodian-Americans followed the troupe around the country as part of a ``defection campaign.'' One Cambodian allegedly tried to kidnap Devi in New York, and others of the troupe received threats, Ms. Blumenthal said. She said there also was an unusual number of love-at-first-sight marriage proposals, apparent efforts to lure dancers to defect. One member of the company claimed that three women fell into his arms declaring love. The American organizers were accused by some of blocking access to the dancers to prevent defections. The U.S. group Lawyers Committee For Human Rights said it had expressed concern and urged State Department interviews of each dancer. All members of the company were interviewed by the State Department and Immigration and Naturalization Service to determine whether any wished to remain in the United States. McAuliff and Blumenthal said it was necessary to restrict some access to the ``beleagured'' company near the end of its tour. Earlier this year, three members left the troupe while it was touring Europe. Proeung Chhieng, director of the university's dance division, said the defections would present some ``small difficulties,'' but said the company expected to continue to travel abroad, including a scheduled December visit to India. He said the defections had taken a toll on the small company, which began to revive classical dance after Vietnamese troops drove out the Khmer Rouge in 1979. The organizers said more than 15,000 people attended peformances during the U.S. tour.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Ballot Issues Before Voters in Eight States
With AM-Green Initiatives-Glance
DOC.TEXT: On windless days, western Washington's majestic Mount Rainier sometimes is obscured by smog from the jammed traffic and smokestacks below. And in many places across the state, housing tracts and shopping malls seem to be marching across forest and meadow. That angers a lot of people, and many blame the state's rapid growth. Residents will decide how to deal with their concern Nov. 6 when they vote on a citizen initiative that would sharply restrict development throughout Washington. Initiatives aimed at correcting perceived environmental ills are on the ballots of several states as a result of petition drives. Among them: - California has four measures that would control emissions, pesticides, offshore oil-drilling and logging. - Oregon voters will decide whether to require recyclable packaging and whether to shut down a nuclear power plant. - South Dakota has initiatives to curb mining and regulate large garbage dumps. - Missouri voters are considering whether to control development along 52 waterways. - Arizona has an initiative to spend $20 million a year on wildlife habitat and open space protection. - Minnesota voters will decide whether to dedicate 40 percent of proceeds of the state lottery to protecting the state's natural resources. New York, which doesn't have citizen initiatives, has on the ballot a $1.975 billion bond issue to acquire land for preservation and to help close aging landfills, promote recycling and otherwise improve the environment. In Washington, Gov. Booth Gardner and other political leaders contend the development initiative is too rigid and could crimp the economy in a myriad of ways. They want voters to give the Legislature a chance to complete growth control legislation begun ths year. Supporters of Initiative 547 say government is too slow, and it's up to citizens to protect the environment. ``We came here 20 years ago for the clean air, the open spaces, the breathtaking view of Mount Rainier. But it's disappearing fast. I get real frustrated at the lack of action by our leaders,'' said Marcia Baird, an Olympia homemaker who intends to vote for the measure. The initiative would force local governments to curtail development of farm, forest and wetlands and impose other land use limits. It also would require developers to pay ``impact fees'' to governments for the cost of providing services to their projects, such as new streets, road widening, freeway ramps and schools. Opponents argue the state can ill afford the proposal's $20 million-a-year administration cost in a rapidly cooling economy, but supporters say inaction carries a heavier price to the environment. Opponents also assert the measure was written hastily and would be subject to numerous court challenges. No poll results have been reported on how the public feels about the initiative, and campaigning for and against is only just getting under way. Supporters have raised $162,000 so far, while opponents have raised $1.2 million, mostly from developers and large businesses. Many politicians and government regulators say citizens are too quick to use initiatives to seek simple, and often illusory, fixes to complex problems. They argue the public wrongly labels careful legislative deliberation as procrastination. ``We don't feel you can regulate on feelings. We believe you have to regulate on some sort of science,'' said James Wells, a pest-management official with the California Department of Agriculture. Among controls in California's sweeping ``Big Green'' initiative would be a ban on pesticides suspected of causing cancer. Agricultural interests contend the move would severely damage the state's economy, which relies heavily on agriculture. James P. Lester, a Colorado State University political scientist who has written extensively on environmental policy at the state level, said: ``There is a growing perception out there that representative democracy is failing when it comes to the environment. And I think direct citizen action through initiatives is just beginning.'' Twenty-six states, the majority in the West, permit citizen initiatives, the National Conference of State Legislatures says. ``When it comes to environmental issues at the ballot box, voters will vote first and think about costs later,'' said Brett Bader, a Washington state economics and political consultant who is leading the campaign against the slow-growth initiative. But the indications are that voters do recognize there are costs and are willing to pay them, said Larry Morandi, an official with the conference of state legislatures. ``From the polls we've seen, people are willing to pay more. There is that awareness that environmental protections aren't free,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Sets Mark for Cocaine Seizure, But U.S. Agents Need Not Worry
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffic in the Pacific Basin is growing like a ``threatening typhoon,'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh warned recently. To view statistics in Japan, it's more like a drizzle. On Friday, the Justice Ministry announced its cocaine haul for 1989 - 30.2 pounds. That's 64 times the total taken the year before - 208 grams, or about a half pound. This year, a record has already been set with the seizure of 52.2 pounds of cocaine in a Yokohama warehouse in February. About 180,250 pounds of cocaine were seized in the United States last year, according to government figures. ``Japan has been very good about keeping hard drugs from the West out. In the past it has been able to do that fairly successfully because borders were closed and there wasn't any internal market for them,'' said Patricia Steinhoff, a University of Hawaii sociologist. Since the problem is so new and substance abuse of any kind is such a private matter in Japan, neither Japanese police nor the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration can accurately say how many people use cocaine. Last year, 88 people were arrested for cocaine-related offenses, according to the Justice Ministry's annual report on crime. For crimes involving other drugs, 340 people were arrested. ``We don't have one clue how many addicts are out there,'' Stan Furce, who operates the DEA's one-man bureau in Tokyo, told The Japan Times recently. ``That's a real dilemma for those trying to get people interested in the problem, because you can't go out and get real facts and real figures to say the problem exists.'' Also, familiar U.S. techniques such as undercover sting operations, seizing assets of suspected drug traffickers and plea bargaining are not practiced in Japan. Laws against laundering money don't exist in Japan's secretive banking system. While the Justice Ministry's report emphasized growing cocaine use in Japan, other drugs have been reported on the rise as well. Seizures of heroin last year, for example, totaled 61 pounds, up 60 percent. Methamphetamine, or ``speed,'' is booming in Japan. Known as ``shabu,'' it flows freely in a nation where stimulant-loaded ``energy'' drinks are regularly advertised on television. Manufactured in bootleg labs in Taiwan and Korea, shabu is mostly sold by Japan's ``yakuza,'' or organized crime groups. More than 16,600 people were arrested last year for using shabu. ``Japan is likely to be viewed as a golden opportunity for drug traffickers. It's rich, it has a history of use of stimulants,'' said a U.S. official who toured Asia with Thornburgh in September.

DOC.HEAD: Black Republican Vs. White Democrat in `Establishment' Race
With AM-1990 Horserace Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The early word in Ohio was that Cincinnati Mayor Charles Luken was a sure bet to succeed his father in the U.S. House and keep the seat in Democratic hands. That was before the Republicans came up with a dream candidate - J. Kenneth Blackwell, a conservative black who himself once was Cincinnati mayor. Now Blackwell and Luken are locked in a tight race for the seat that seven-term Democrat Thomas Luken hoped to pass on to his son. Each candidate claims his internal polls show him leading. Blackwell is among three black congressional candidates hoping to become the first black Republicans in the House in 56 years. His party is sparing no expense to help him out. Appearing on his behalf have been George Bush, Barbara Bush, Dan Quayle, Oliver North and Jack Kemp, until recently Blackwell's boss at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. ``People in this district are offended that these inside-the-beltway celebrities are telling working people who to vote for,'' says Luken. Luken is ``whining about the fact that the Republican Party has targeted this race as a very, very important race,'' counters Blackwell. The race is about ``who's running to be part of Washington and who's running to change it,'' says Luken, who wants to ``get up there and shake up things.'' Blackwell says his opponent ``would be part of the problem in Washington. He would get along by going along.'' ``What you really have here are two establishment candidates,'' says Ohio State University political scince professor Herb Asher. Blackwell and Luken were allies when they served together on the Cincinnati city council. They agree on issues such as cutting the capital gains tax, giving presidents line-item veto power and gun control. Both oppose abortion, but Blackwell won the endorsement of the Right to Life organization. Blackwell also snagged the endorsement of Cincinnati's dominant daily newspaper, The Enquirer, which said he would be ``a national figure from the day of his election.'' The tone of the campaign has been harsh, and each candidate has blamed the other for the turn it has taken. Blackwell accused Luken of politicking on taxpayers' time by making long-distance calls from the mayor's office to Washington. Luken anticipated the allegation and reimbursed the city months before Blackwell made the charge. Luken said Blackwell leveled the allegation because ``he thinks I've got him'' on a possible Federal Election Commission violation. The Ohio Republican Party is paying for slick direct-mail literature, and the National Republican Congressional Committee is supplementing Blackwell's staff. Luken has asked the FEC to rule on whether Republicans exceeded the party's legal limits. Blackwell has been criticized by local black leaders for opposing the 1990 Civil Rights Act to pick up political support. Frank Allison, president of the Cincinnati chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Blackwell ``sold his soul for a mess of votes.'' Blackwell accused Allison of ``insulting my parentage and integrity,'' saying the bill would impose an unfair quota system. Blackwell said he agrees with the bill's goals but not with its way of achieving them, and Luken largely shares that view. ``My position is more in line with the president's - that there is a better civil rights bill out there,'' Luken said. Retiring Rep. Thomas Luken has been an electoral exception in the Republican-dominated congressional district that includes part of Cincinnati and suburban Hamilton County. He held the seat while voters were choosing Republicans for county offices, the county's other congressional seat and the presidency. ``There's nothing easy about winning for Democrats in this county,'' said Democratic county co-chair Don Driehaus. Two-thirds of the district's voters live in the suburbs, small towns and rural delivery routes between Cincinnati and the Indiana border. Middle-class whites of German descent and transplants from Appalachia are the largest voter blocs. Black voters ``are about 14 percent, and in a very, very close race that's a significant number,'' said Blackwell. He's confident he can pry away some of the votes that used to go to Thomas Luken. But Charles Luken thinks he'll pull more than half of the black vote. ``Race is not a central issue of the campaign, but it will be a factor,'' said Asher, the political science professor. Blackwell is ``not the candidate of the poor and the underclass and the Rainbow Coalition. He's the Republican candidate who happens to be black,'' Asher said.

DOC.HEAD: Prejudice Remains Despite Repeal of Apartheid Laws
DOC.TEXT: The desegregation of swimming pools, toilets and other facilities once reserved for whites has changed little for millions of blacks who still face prejudice, poverty and hopelessness. Repeal of the Separate Amenities Act on Oct. 15 was another step toward President F.W. de Klerk's promised end to apartheid. ``Whites Only'' signs were one of its most potent symbols. Black leaders applaud the end of segregated facilities, but they say prejudice is not disappearing and blacks still are excluded from many aspects of life. Few whites appear willing to live with blacks, and there are few signs that racial attitudes are changing, they say. The Sowetan, South Africa's leading black newspaper, reported disillusionment among blacks because their lot has failed to improve with the scrapping of apartheid laws. ``The change they thought (was) upon them is now evaporating,'' the paper said. ``We do not doubt de Klerk's sincerity in wanting a new dispensation for this country. We, however, wonder if this country has the capacity to achieve this, for the government and white society at all levels are still riddled with racism.'' Sy Makaringe, a black journalist who used what had been a restricted swimming pool on the day the law was repealed, said white attitudes had not changed. ``It was clear that, for local whites, my presence was a hard pill to swallow,'' he said. ``Two white men who were in the pool left immediately after seeing me.'' Zach de Beer, leader of the white anti-apartheid Democratic Party, agreed that ending apartheid laws was not enough. He said blacks and whites must live together and share every aspect of life. ``Positive steps must be taken to bring people together in sport, recreation and society,'' he said. Many leaders, both black and white, admit privately they don't how to get the races together. Anti-apartheid leaders say that, despite the repeal of apartheid laws, most blacks still live in terrible poverty, confined to black townships with little or no hope of improving their lives. Black leaders say winning the right to use a public toilet is meaningless if you remain a second-class citizen in a world of white privilege. They contend that economic inequality will preserve de facto apartheid. Whites control the economy and some whites are certain to use their wealth to preserve segregation. Local councils controlled by the pro-apartheid Conservative Party intend to exclude most blacks from public facilities by imposing membership or user fees blacks cannot afford. Some observers say whites will retreat into expensive private clubs and other restricted facilites. The Conservative Party holds that blacks and whites cannot live together in peace. Party leaders demand a white homeland and accuse de Klerk of trying to destroy whites. ``F.W. de Klerk is acting like a despot and an unscrupulous dictator,'' Conservative official Andries du Toit said. Government leaders and others say any attempts to preserve unofficial apartheid will lead to confrontation and threaten efforts toward a political solution to racial problems. The government has said it will oppose local councils that try to preserve racial segregation. ``The strategem of erecting financial barriers to keep blacks out will be seen for what it is: racism in a different guise,'' said The Star, a leading anti-apartheid newspaper. ``Black people will hammer at the doors if they are not opened graciously. They will batter them down if they not opened to all.'' Black leaders criticize the government for not ending all restrictions immediately. Some major apartheid laws remain in effect, including the Group Areas Act, which segregates living areas, and Population Registration Act, which classifies South Africans by color. De Klerk's government is wary of moving against the Group Areas Act for fear of offending whites who are apprehensive about changes already made. Plans to open white schools to blacks have made little progress and officials say lack of funds is delaying hospital integration. De Klerk has said registration by race will end only when black and white leaders agree on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Ruling Breaks New Ground In Prosecution Of Women
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: Abortion rights advocates say a Massachusetts judge's dismissal of drug charges against a woman whose son was born with cocaine in his system will help their fight. Until last week, a pregnant woman in Massachusetts who abused drugs or alcohol faced the possibility of criminal charges if her abuse harmed her fetus. But in a 19-page decision, a Superior Court judge outlined constitutional privacy rights for pregnant women. In a ruling that could influence other judges in Massachusetts and elsewhere, she said the state could not pursue charges against pregnant women that it did not bring against other people. ``No court has ever reached this constitutional issue before,'' said Lynn Paltrow, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer in New York. The ACLU and several women's groups promised to cite the Massachusetts decision in at least six other cases pending in states, including Texas, Illinois and Florida. ``This will appear in every brief in every prosecution nationwide,'' said Nancy Gertner, a lawyer who represented 20 different groups interested in the Massachusetts case. The prosecutors in the cases say their goal is to discourage pregnant women from drug abuse and similar ills that would cause her and her fetus harm. But Plymouth County Superior Court Judge Suzanne DelVecchio cited alternatives to prosecution of women whose habits hurt their fetuses - such as education and free medical care. ``By imposing criminal sanctions, a woman may turn away from seeking prenatal care for fear of being discovered,'' she wrote. In throwing out the case against 24-year-old Josephine Pellegrini, a mother of three, DelVecchio also said that government should not interfere with the ``intimate and fundamental bond'' between a woman and the fetus she bears. ``This court will not permit the destruction of this relationship by the prosecution,'' she said. Pellegrini of Brockton had been indicted by a Plymouth County grand jury in September 1989 on charges of distributing cocaine to a minor and cocaine possession. A drug screening by doctors found cocaine in the urine of her son, Nathan, born July 2, 1989. A leading opponent of abortion said DelVecchio's decision highlights the need to overturn the landmark Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. ``I'm sure nobody in the country ever expected Roe vs. Wade meant to protect a woman's right to inflict illegal drugs on an unborn child,'' said Ruth Pakaluk, president of the Massachusetts Citizens for Life. ``One of the reasons this whole area of law makes no sense is, if it is legal to kill an unborn child, how on earth can it be illegal to inflict a little harm?'' she continued. ``As long as abortion on demand is the law, all the rest of this is schizophrenic.'' Pakaluk and her colleagues argue a fetus is a human being and should enjoy the freedoms and protections of everyone else. ``The protections of a fetus shouldn't be superior or hostile to the interests of a pregnant woman,'' countered Joyce Cunha, associate director of the abortion rights group MassChoice. Women's advocates say the fetal rights cases are critical because once a pregnant woman is held liable for some damage to her fetus, the door will be wide open for regulating her every move. ACLU's Paltrow said states might try to dictate ``what she eats, where she works and whether she can change the (cat) litter.'' Cat feces sometimes carry a disease organism that can be harmful to fetuses. Abortion rights advocates acknowledge DelVecchio's ruling does not carry beyond her county jurisdiction. But with no other written guidance on the subject, it carries unusual weight. ``The absence of any decision like this meant every prosecutor nationwide could decide how to reinterpret common law,'' Gertner said. ``It was anarchy. Every politically ambitious prosecutor could decide this would be his contribution to the drug war.'' In Greenville, S.C., this month, a woman who gave birth to a cocaine-addicted baby was sentenced to 10 years in prison after authorities said she repeatedly failed to complete drug programs designed to help her overcome her problems. On the same day that mother pleaded guilty to charges of child neglect, a Spartanburg County magistrate ruled the state's child neglect law can be applied to an unborn fetus in the case of a woman whose baby boy was born with symptoms of heroin addiction.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Conviction of 2 Live Crew Would Be Just Common Sense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with closing arguments under way. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Group leader...'.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor urged jurors today to use their common sense and deliver an obscenity conviction against three members of 2 Live Crew for a nightclub performance of their bawdy rap music. ``This was a plain, simple, nasty act,'' Assistant State Attorney Pedro Dijols said in closing arguments. ``That's all it was. It's unbelievable they can come in here with a straight face and tell you something different.'' He urged jurors to review two tapes of the performance, even though prosecution witnesses had difficulty deciphering their own recordings. After quoting some of the Miami group's profane lyrics, Dijols asked, ``How can you say it's not offensive?'' Defense attorneys for the three defendants also were delivering closing arguments today, and the six-member jury was expected to receive the case this afternoon. Jurors must balance the defense testimony of a professor who said 2 Live Crew performs with artistic integrity and a sense of history against a detective's report that the group promoted indecent behavior at the club. Group leader Luther Campbell and members Chris ``Fresh Kid Ice'' Wongwon and Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross were arrested on misdemeanor obscenity charges after an adults-only concert June 10 in nearby Hollywood. The three face up to a year in prison and $1,000 in fines if convicted. Broward County sheriff's Detective Debbie Werder spent four hours on the witness stand Friday attempting to translate a scratchy, often inaudible tape she made of the group's show. Jurors burst into laughter when Werder described the type of dancing she saw at the concert as ``humping.'' Three jurors laughed so hard that they cried, and the prosecution asked for a short recess. After the break, Werder testified: ``A lot of couples were dancing like they were having intercourse.'' The jury also heard Henry Louis Gates Jr., a professor of English literature at Duke University and literary critic of black art and culture, describe 2 Live Crew's lyrics as an art form called ``signifying.'' Signifying is a form of rhythmic teasing and cajoling, often peppered with lewd or off-color remarks that can be meant as insult or compliment, said Gates, whose book ``The Signifying Monkey'' won last year's American Book Award. ``It was the way the black people could fight against the oppression of their slave masters,'' said Gates who is black. ``And rapping is a contemporary form of signifying.'' ``There's no call to violence here. What you hear is great humor, great joy and great boisterousness,'' he said. ``It's a joke. It's a parody, and parody is one of the most venerated forms of art.''

DOC.HEAD: Murder of Young Secretary Rivets Public, Stumps Police
DOC.TEXT: The young secretary's family first thought something was amiss when she didn't return home for dinner. Later, her body was found with 29 stab wounds. So began the ``Mystery of Via Poma,'' which has capitivated Italians for more than two months with its lurid twists and host of suspects and possible motives. In a country where people have become hardened to daily Mafia killings, the murder of 21-year-old Simonetta Cesaroni seems to have struck a nerve by exposing the vulnerability of ordinary Italians. ``You have a nice, pretty girl from the suburbs going to work in the middle of the summer while dreaming of going to the seashore,'' said sociologist Franco Ferrarotti of the University of Rome. ``Instead she ends up in the cemetery, the victim of a brutal killing. She's seen as a sacrificial lamb.'' Nearly every day, newspapers report some new development or plot in the ``Via Poma'' case, named for the small street in Rome's bustling Prati neighborhood where the murder took place. Most murder cases in Italy receive standard coverage on crime pages of local newspapers and quickly fade away. But this one has ingredients to set it apart: the shock value of its savage brutality, the hint of sex, disappearing evidence, mysterious blood stains, and a range of suspects. Ms. Cesaroni was found murdered the night of Aug. 7 in the offices of a youth hostel association where she worked. It was to have been her last day of work before joining the rest of her friends and family - and most of the rest of Italy - for the traditional August holidays. When she didn't come home for dinner, her family sensed something was wrong and her sister and others went to the office. They found Ms. Cesaroni's naked body lying in a pool of blood. She had been stabbed 29 times with a paper cutter. There was no sign of sexual abuse. Investigators said Ms. Cesaroni apparently knew her assailant or assailants. Three days after the murder, police announced the arrest of Pietro Vanacore, the 58-year-old doorman and janitor at the building. This might have closed the case, but after 20 days in jail Vanacore was released. A court ruled there was insufficient evidence to hold him. Newspapers immediately focused on another suspect, Ms. Cesaroni's employer, but he had an alibi. The case apparently rests now on blood stains found on the door of the office. Investigators said the blood is apparently that of the assassin. Nineteen people, including the doorman and his wife, have been ordered to submit to DNA tests to see if their blood type matches the stains. Police still have not figured out the motive. Was it sex, drugs, a love affair? ``If the police, magistrates, judges and press had conspired to make an interesting case, they couldn't have done any better than this one,'' Ferrarotti said. ``This is a fantastic story. You need an Agatha Christie to figure it out.'' But the newsmagazine L'Espresso suggested the murder was a sign of a ``a new, terrible sickness in our society'' that could lead any of the most ordinary people to commit such an act. Could it be, L'Espresso asked, that the crime was committed ``by the next-door neighbor, the friend, the colleague or the acquaintance one meets regularly in the elevator?''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Moving Top-line Tanks from Europe to Saudi Desert
With AM-Gulf-Anti-War, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA1
DOC.TEXT: The United States is shifting several hundred of its best tanks from Europe to Saudi Arabia to counter Iraq's battle-seasoned armored units. The U.S. tanks are better able to withstand chemical and nuclear attacks, but their guns still may not have the range of those on Iraq's best tank. The advanced M1A1 Main Battle Tanks, equipped with a more powerful 120mm gun, will be in Saudi Arabia by the end of the year, replacing older M1s that were brought from the United States, a spokesman said. The disclosure came as the first British Challenger tanks intended for use by Britain's 7th Armored Brigade, the ``Desert Rats,'' rolled off a ship at an eastern Saudi port. The Challengers also fire a 120mm gun and are protected by what British officers call the world's best tank armor. A statement by the U.S. command in Saudi Arabia said the M1A1s were being drawn from storage areas in Europe. Despite the transfer, it said, they would continue to be counted as part of the U.S. strength level permitted under the pending treaty on Conventional Forces in Europe. The treaty, to be signed by the end of this year, calls for military cutbacks by both NATO and Warsaw Pact forces. ``We are proposing to our NATO allies that these tanks continue to be counted under the CFE treaty, thus leaving NATO's tank destruction a requirement under the treaty unchanged,'' the statement said. The Soviets already had withdrawn some of their armored units from the European theater, in keeping with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 1988 promise of unilateral reductions. U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia said the transfer would cost about $4.8 million. No personnel will be moved with the tanks, they said. The M1A1s will provide ``improved capabilities'' over the M1 Abrams tanks brought to Saudi Arabia with four U.S. Army units already deployed under Operation Desert Shield. A military spokesman, Maj. Doug Bidle, said he did not know which unit would receive the new tanks or what would be done with the M1s already in Saudi Arabia. The M1s are used by the 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored Divisions and the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division and 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade. The latter two units already have an advanced version of the Abrams tank, fitted with improved firing systems for the standard 105mm cannon. The 3rd Armored Cavalry Brigade, currently on its way to Saudi Arabia, is bringing its own M1A1 tanks, Bidle said. The M1A1 has improved crew protection against nuclear, biological and chemical attack, and its 120mm cannon is more of a match for the Iraqis' best tank, the Soviet-made T-72. Even so, the U.S. tanks could still be outgunned by the T-72s, which have a 125mm gun believed capable of hitting targets at up to 3,000 yards, compared to the 2,400-yard range reported for the German-designed gun carried by the M1A1. Both tanks, as well as the Challenger, are protected by advanced armor first developed by the British and adopted by several countries. The T-72s are said to be more heavily armored in front where a head-on shot would be likely to hit. The Iraqis, according to some reports, also are upgrading their older Soviet tanks with better armor and other equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Ballot Measures at a Glance
With AM-Green Initiatives
DOC.TEXT: Here's a look at environmental issues facing voters around the nation on Nov. 6: - California: The broadest citizen initiative, nicknamed ``Big Green,'' would gradually curb auto and other emissions to combat global warming, preserve ancient redwood forests, ban oil development in state waters and bar pesticides suspected of causing cancer. Other initiatives would protect fish, broaden anti-toxics law, protect forests and commercial fish runs and address other environmental issues. - Washington: An initiative would create two regional boards, appointed by the governor, to oversee and enforce land use planning at the local and regional levels. Local governments would be required to form planning boards and designate lands suitable for development based on standards set by the initiative. The local boards also would be required to designate and protect forest, farm and wetlands. Developers would be required to pay ``impacts fees'' to cover the cost of government services, such as new roads or schools. Governments that failed to plan could be denied tax revenue and state grants. - Oregon: One initiative would require all food and product packaging to meet one of three recycling standards by Jan. 1, 1993. Packaging would have to contain at least 50 percent recyclable material, or be made of material of which 60 percent could be recycled in Oregon by 2002, or be able to be reused at least five times. Another measure would shut down, at least temporarily, the Trojan nuclear power plant about 40 miles northwest of Portland. - Missouri: An initiative proposes protecting 52 natural waterways, mainly in the Ozarks, by banning new dams and restricting landfills and dumping, septic tanks and structures near the waterways. All-terrain vehicle and loud motorboats would be banned from some streams. - South Dakota: One initiative would limit active large-scale gold or silver mining operations in the Black Hills to a total of 3,100 acres. Once the limit was reached, miners could launch new operations only by shutting and reclaiming existing mines. Another initiative would require legislative approval for large-scale garbage dumps. - Arizona: One initiative would require spending $20 million a year in state lottery receipts on wildlife habitat protection, parks, trails and other environmental endeavors. Another would charge the Department of Environmental Quality with finding ways to reduce solid waste in the state by 20 percent by 2010. - Minnesota: An initiative would dedicate until 2001 at least 40 percent of the net proceeds of the state lottery to a trust fund charged with protecting wildlife, open spaces and other natural resources. - New York: A $1.975 billion bond issue, put on the ballot by the Legislature, would be used for environmental protection endeavors. The largest chunk of the money, $800 million, would be used to buy and preserve land.

DOC.HEAD: Cowabunga! Ninja Outfits Tops For Halloween
DOC.TEXT: Watch out, dudes! Those lean, mean, green fighting machines are coming out of their shells this Halloween. But don't have a cow, man - Bart Simpson also will be on doorsteps threatening his tricks for treats. Rentals of Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles costumes are among the most popular get-ups this year, a carryover from the characters' box office success, costume shop owners say. ``The Ninja Turtles are going like crazy,'' said Tammy Dooley, warehouse manager for Master's Tuxedo in Charleston. ``Everybody just seems to be loving these turtles.'' ``We've had 57 calls for them in the past week,'' said Jennifer Rose as she scanned the inventory list at the Costume Co. in the Boston suburb of Arlington. ``Kids, adults, male and female. ``We've had so many requests, we're having to turn people down for them. There's a lot of people who ask us if they think people will cancel out. We tell them `not likely.''' Lookalikes of Fox Television's Simpson family are doing well in some places. Costumers who want to rent Simpsons outfits are popping up almost as much as Bart's bulging eyes at Stages costume shop in Wheeling, about 30 miles west of Pittsburgh. ``All the Simpsons are doing pretty good,'' shop spokesman Dan Fincham said. ``The greatest thing about the Simpsons is there's the mom and the dad and the son, so you get a lot of trios like a short guy or a kid and his parents,'' he said. ``The head's the most important part.'' But for those who are stuck on being green this Halloween, it's a Ninja or nothing. Theresa Saidy, owner of Adele's of Hollywood in Los Angeles, said Wednesday she's received 20 to 30 calls a day for turtle costumes. And don't be shellshocked at the price of an outfit. A Ninja costume rental goes for $45 to $90, depending on the quality, Saidy said. Some customers won't settle for just any turtle costume. The turtle characters, who are named for Renaissance artists, have distinct personalities. ``The kids like Leonardo and Michelangelo,'' said Lisa Marshall, owner of Balloon Express in Clarksburg, which is 100 miles northeast of Charleston. ``They don't like Raphael for some reason. They say he's the mean one. He's a know-it-all.'' Costumes portraying detective Dick Tracy have had scattered success in the wake of the box office hit. Among women, rock singer Madonna, Depression Era flappers, belly dancers and antebellum outfits are popular. ``There's a real lean toward the southern belle, Victorian-type costumes,'' Fincham said. ``The really scary stuff isn't as popular any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Buys Gas Masks from Eastern Europe
With AM-Gulf-Anti-War, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia is buying millions of surplus gas masks from Eastern Europe for areas considered in range of an Iraqi chemical weapons attack, officials said Saturday. The masks, arriving aboard Soviet Anatov-124 cargo planes, are part of new civil defense plans that include air raid sirens and evacuation routes in the event of war. Officials were reluctant to discuss the full extent of the plans, fearing jitters among the civilian population. The sirens, for example, were installed two weeks ago but were not tested because ``they don't want to panic people,'' said one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's basically a psychological measure. You have to give the people something to make them feel better,'' another official said. Officials said the kingdom started shopping for up to 4 million gas masks for both Saudi citizens and foreign residents after Saddam Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Manufacturers in Britain and Western Europe did not have enough, but the armies of the Soviet Union and East Bloc nations were eager to sell, they said. It was not known how many gas masks will be available from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``Soviet troops being pulled out of Eastern Europe don't need chemical weapons masks,'' said one official. Col. Saoud al-Zuneifer, a civil defense official, told the newspaper Al-Riyadh this week that the masks will be available for about $90 each. But for those who cannot afford the price, the gas masks will be handed out free. ``You can't expect a goatherd or a taxi driver to be able to afford to buy a gas mask,'' said one official. The bulk of the masks will be available near the border with Kuwait and Iraq, but cities such as Riyadh and Dammam in the eastern province will also get them. Western and southern provinces in the kingdom of 12 million have been deemed out of range of any artillery or airplanes that Iraq might use to try to deliver chemical weapons. In the chemical attack on the Iraqi Kurdish village of Halabja in March 1988, Baghdad used airplanes flying in crop-dusting style and barrels dropped from transport planes. But military officials say Iraqi planes would have trouble penetrating Saudi radar and anti-aircraft defenses. Short range artillery could drop shells near the border, but they could be knocked out with Patriot missile batteries, officials say. Even if a plane or missile did get through, gas would likely dissipate quickly in the hot, dry climate, they say. Saudi Arabia is not the only nation gearing up to protect itself against a possible chemical weapons attack. Israel has begun nationwide distribution of gas masks.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Faces Significant Chance of Jail for Drug Possession
DOC.TEXT: Like many other first-time drug offenders to go before a federal judge for sentencing, Mayor Marion Barry faces the prospect this week of being ordered behind bars for possessing crack cocaine. Even though he was convicted of only a misdemeanor, figures compiled by the U.S. Sentencing Commission show that the mayor has a good chance of being ordered to serve time. The study showed that 39.5 percent of 370 defendants convicted in federal courts for the first time of simple drug possession between Nov. 1, 1987, and March 1, 1989, were imprisoned. Another 3.8 percent were ordered to serve weekends in local jails while undergoing drug treatment. Judges placed 52.2 percent on probation and the rest were not sanctioned at all. Federal prosecutors who obtained the misdemeanor drug possession conviction against Barry last summer have not yet submitted their sentencing request to U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. But comments that Barry's defense lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, made Friday at a hearing indicates that the probation officer who filed a pre-sentence report in the case recommended a sentence ranging between two months and eight months in prison. The mayor was convicted in August of simple possession by a jury that acquitted him of another misdemeanor count and deadlocked on another dozen charges, including lying to a grand jury by denying under oath that he had used drugs. Under the law, Barry faces up to a year in prison when he goes before Jackson on Friday. Jackson is required to apply federal sentencing guidelines, which establish ranges of prison time that depend upon the severity of the crime and other circumstances, such as the degree of the defendant's participation. Probation officer Arthur Carrington was assigned to conduct the pre-sentence investigation and submit a report to Jackson with a calculation of what prison term, if any, the guidelines call for. The judge could disagree with Carrington's calculation of the sentencing range. Mundy objected to language stating that the mayor had failed to accept responsibility for his criminal behavior, stating that ``it would have been very perilous'' for the mayor to admit drug possession when prosecutors still are continuing their investigation of the mayor. Acceptance of responsibility would give the defendant a two-point reduction from the offense score that is calculated under the guidelines. Mundy's comments indicate that the probation office found that Barry should not receive such credit, thereby setting the offense score at six - the base figure for possession of crack cocaine. Such a score would set the sentence range at zero to six months. But Mundy raised yet another objection; this one to findings in the report that the mayor had obstructed justice. The guideline formula calls for raising the offense score two points for defendants who intimidated witnesses, suborned perjury, destroyed evidence or otherwise obstructed justice. A two-point addition in Barry's case would raise the offense score to eight, thereby setting the sentence range at two months to eight months. Under the guidelines, Jackson would have to make a special finding to justify any sentence less than two months. Mundy's comments did not indicate what evidence of obstruction of justice was cited by the probation office. But one possibility is the trial testimony of convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who told jurors he used crack cocaine in a downtown hotel with the mayor and during a vacation at the Virgin Islands. Lewis also testified that Barry acquiesced when Lewis told the mayor he would deny to a grand jury that he used drugs with the mayor. The probation office's finding could be seized upon by prosecutors to support an argument that the mayor should be imprisoned. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens has indicated he would make such a request.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plans Civil Rights Veto But Leaves Door Open for Deal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with bill received, amendments readied; tightens throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is holding off on vetoing a sweeping civil rights bill while sending compromise language to Congress in hopes of getting a measure he could sign, administration officials said today. White House officials today were sending Congress a package of changes that addressed some of the principal objections of civil rights advocates whose legislation Bush opposes. In the meantime, Bush will hold off on his promised veto of the civil rights bill that arrived at the White House today from Capitol Hill, officials said. Instead he is sending Congress proposed amendments to the bill in hopes of getting a joint resolution to supplant the original bill. ``Assuming that we continue on this course, it represents an effort by the president to try and make a currently unacceptable bill acceptable,'' said Bush's legislative liaison Fred McClure. Congressional opponents of an earlier White House proposal contended the administration's language would have focused on employer intentions rather than keying on whether certain employment practices themselves were discriminatory. One of the key changes being offered, according to an official who spoke on condition of anonymity, was elimination of the word ``intended'' from what the White House had proposed earlier. The bill that cleared Congress on Wednesday is the civil rights movement's top legislative priority and would overturn six job discrimination decisions that raised a furor when the Supreme Court handed them down last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in the most extreme cases of job discrimination. The major conflict, however, has come over features that would make it easier to take employers to court over their employment practices. Bush has been saying these provisions are so harsh they would force companies to adopt hiring quotas - something sponsors dispute. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said it was unclear if Congress would approve changes now that it had rejected over the last nine months. One sponsor, Sen. James Jeffords, R-Vt., said after speaking with Bush on Friday it was possible that follow-up legislation could ease White House concerns and be signed as a companion to the original bill. ``There has been movement on both sides,'' Jeffords said. Meanwhile, Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, said Bush told him Thursday by telephone that he was exploring ways to avoid a veto, including passage of follow-up legislation. Civil rights demonstrators have paraded in front of the White House in hopes of pressuring Bush to relent and sign the bill. Fitzwater said that the ``president certainly wants a strong civil rights bill. He is committed to it. Let's erase this legal question and make it a true civil rights bill.'' ``There's been nothing to change our belief that it's a quota bill. The only issue is, is there any way to get it changed at this late date in a way that will be satisfactory,'' the spokesman added.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ruling Set for Monday in Unprecedented Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge's upcoming ruling in an unprecedented custody struggle between a surrogate mother and the genetic parents of a baby boy may end only the first chapter of the bitter dispute, attorneys said. The decision by Orange County Superior Court Judge Richard Parslow is expected to be issued Monday. But both sides say it likely will be appealed, leaving the future of the 4-week-old child again hanging in the balance. ``I know we won't win here, but we will win in the appeals court,'' surrogate Anna Johnson, 29, said outside court last week, echoing her attorneys' pessimism about how Parslow might rule. Although the appellate court would be asked to take the case up quickly, there could be a delay of several months, said Diane Marlowe, one of Ms. Johnson's lawyers. Ms. Johnson is seeking parental rights and a say in the boy's upbringing although she is genetically unrelated to him. Genetic parents Crispina and Mark Calvert insist they should be recognized as the sole parents. The Calverts, who agreed to pay Ms. Johnson $10,000 to carry their test-tube embryo, have temporary custody of the boy. They call him Christopher, but he remains without a legal name until custody is decided. Parslow has noted several times that this case differs from the famed Baby M case of New Jersey because the surrogate mother seeking custody in that case was also the baby's genetic parent. Attorneys have said the Calvert-Johnson dispute could break new legal ground because a genetically unrelated surrogate never has sought custody. In the six-day hearing that concluded last week, Ms. Johnson's attorneys tried to show she developed an unexpected but deep emotional attachment to the baby during the pregnancy that must not be severed. The Calverts offered evidence about the importance of the genetic link. They also attempted to cast doubt on Ms. Johnson's motives, claiming she was motivated by a thirst for publicity and money, not love of the child. Ms. Marlowe and partner Richard Gilbert have said they believe Parslow will rule against their client on ``emotion'' rather than existing state law, which they said recognizes the birth mother as the legal mother of a child. ``We feel if the judge ruled on the law, we've won the case. We don't think the court has been able to do that'' and will try to create new law, Ms. Marlowe said Friday. ``I don't believe the case is being decided on emotion,'' countered Christian Van Deusen, the Calverts' attorney. ``The case is being decided on facts and what little law we have as guideposts.'' Parslow has conducted the case in a quiet and low-key manner, generally allowing attorneys leeway in questioning of witnesses and setting aside some court formalities. Van Deusen noted that both he and Harold LaFlamme, the court-appointed attorney for the child, have urged the judge to find that the evidence concerning genetics is the ``controlling evidence.'' Van Deusen said Friday he will probably appeal if the judge's ruling fails to recognize certain major points. ``Most importantly, we are asking him to find that, as a matter of public policy, genetic parents of a child have to be the legal parents of that child,'' Van Deusen said. The judge also should rule that someone cannot use ``false pretenses to obtain a unique genetic individual that a husband and wife have created.'' Ms. Johnson, a single mother of a toddler, and Mrs. Calvert, 36, met while working as nurses at a Santa Ana hospital. Despite Nobel Prize, Gorbachev Losing Grip on Republics
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev began last week by winning the Nobel Peace Prize and closed it by persuading the legislature to approve his latest economic reform plan. But Tuesday through Thursday weren't so hot. Although the prize added luster to Gorbachev's already shining global image, it gave him little protection from domestic critics. They accuse him of doing too little too late to appease the 15 Soviet republics and prevent them from leaving the Soviet Union. The two largest republics, Russia and the Ukraine, stepped closer to breaking with the national government during the week. The continuing disintegration of central authority may prompt Gorbachev to rely more heavily on the sweeping executive powers entrusted to him last month by the national legislature. But a bold assertion of emergency power could kill Soviet democracy as it is being born, and doom Gorbachev to the fate of centuries of Russian reformers who began their reigns with good deeds but ended them as tyrants. Gorbachev was jovial Friday night after the Supreme Soviet legislature approved his moderate reform plan. The plan would partially reverse decades of central planning, allow the market rather than the government to set most prices, and encourage private enterprise. The preceding three days gave him plenty of reasons to growl, however. On Tuesday, Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian Federation, criticized Gorbachev's reforms as half-baked and ``doomed to fail,'' and steered his repoblic toward far more radical measures. On Wednesday, Grigory Yavlinsky, an architect of Yeltsin's reform package, threatened to quit his job as deputy prime minister of Russia because he said Gorbachev's plan would trigger disastrous price hikes. On Thursday, Prime Minister Vitaly Masol of the Ukraine was forced to resign after widespread student protests that signaled a growing separatist movement in the second largest and potentially most troublesome Soviet republic. Previously, the Ukraine had been relatively quiet compared to the Baltic or Caucasus republics. On Friday, Gennady Filshin, another Russian deputy prime minister, accused Gorbachev of ``massive attacks'' on the republic's right to control its economy and politics. Gorbachev might have expected better. Receiving the Nobel Prize, he had commented Monday, was ``an appreciation of the cause we are all working for.'' But the democratic forces Gorbachev helped release are now working far faster than he is to decentralize economic and political power. Since Yeltsin was elected Russian president in May and his legislature declared sovereignty, Russia has set the tone for relations between the central government and the republics. Nearly all of them have declared some form of independence or sovereignty. Now Yeltsin and Gorbachev are at loggerheads when cooperation is crucial: the 66-page economic reform document approved Friday leaves it to the republics to enact laws to enforce the plans. Russia and the other republics, however, show little sign of cooperating. On the other hand, Gorbachev has a fall-back position - he has broad executive powers that the legislature granted him last month to carry out the economic reforms. On Oct. 4, in his first decree under the powers, Gorbachev authorized stiff fines for businesses that do not meet delivery quotas under the central planning system - the very system he says he wants to do away with. But it's an open question whether Gorbachev has either the authority or the means to enforce that decree or any others he may promulgate. ``In the current political situation, the economy is not going anywhere. You can issue decrees, but no one will pay attention,'' said Ed Hewett, a Soviet economic expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington. ``Even if you produced a very detailed plan that was very radical, but gave it to a government that has a reputation of doing nothing, little could happen,'' Hewett said. An agency will be created to monitor compliance with delivery quotas, according to two top Gorbachev economic aides, Nikolai Petrakov and Leonid Abalkin. But the president might rely on the KGB security police or armed forces to enforce the decree, and that could kill the democratic reforms. Using the police to bolster central planning does not seem a likely way to foster a decentralized market system. Gorbachev is not the first Kremlin leader to face the dilemma of reform versus authority, according to the emigre Russian historian Alexander Yanov, whose articles have been published this year in the Soviet press. Czar Ivan IV began his rule in 1533 by fostering democracy and convening a parliament called the ``zemski sobor.'' Things fell apart, though, and he resorted to terror, becoming known to history as Ivan the Terrible. Peter the Great opened Russia's ``window on the West'' in the early 18th century and reformed nearly all aspects of the government. But to do so he employed extreme personal power, and some historians call him a despot. Alexander II, the ``czar liberator,'' freed Russian serfs in the 1860s. But his tough measures against dissent helped lead to his assassination in 1881. Gorbachev may have had a tough week, but it looks like the coming winter could bring more cause for sorrow. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Bryan Brumley, The Associated Press bureau chief in Moscow, has covered Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Suspension of California Financier From HUD Programs Upheld
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd and 5th grafs to UPDATE with efforts to contact Rozet and correct style.
DOC.TEXT: California financier A. Bruce Rozet allowed numerous problems ``to run amok'' in the huge portfolio of subsidized apartments he managed, said a judge who has upheld his suspension from federal housing programs. Administrative Judge Jean S. Cooper accused Rozet's company, Housing Resources Management Inc., of ``negligence and arrogance.'' Tenants' security deposits were misused and the Department of Housing and Urban Development was improperly billed for rent subsidies when apartments were vacant, the judge concluded Thursday. Rozet is chairman of the firm, and Deane Earl Ross is chief executive. Telephone listings for Rozet and his company could not be found in the Los Angeles area Saturday, but Rozet, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser, earlier contended he was the victim of a partisan vendetta by the Republican administration. ``Too many problems, serious and still unresolved, were created, exacerbated, and allowed to run amok. The improper conduct of the corporation must be imputed to'' the top officials, said Cooper, who also faulted HUD's oversight of the company. HUD General Counsel Frank Keating told The Associated Press on Saturday, ``We're thrilled about the ruling. This is the first of many actions that (HUD Secretary Jack) Kemp insists be taken to turn around the quality of living in low-income housing.'' Cooper's ruling came on an appeal from Rozet and included an order that the suspension remain in effect until an ongoing government investigation of Rozet's business and any ensuing disciplinary proceedings are completed. Rozet and his affiliates were suspended from HUD in January after nearly one-third of the 350 subsidized housing projects he held were found to have financial or physical problems. Federal officials had inspected property Rozet managed in Oklahoma and in the District of Columbia. Rozet handles tens of thousands of subsidized apartments.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adopts Multiparty System
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted Saturday to end 15 years of leftist one-party rule, permitting competing political parties and secret balloting, the state news agency reported. The move could help break a stalemate in the 13-year-old civil war that has killed some 600,000 people. Proposals for a multiparty system previously were adopted by the ruling FRELIMO party's policy-making Central Committee. Approval by the People's Assembly, Mozambique's parliament, had been expected. The AIM news agency said the changes adopted Saturday cleared the way for new laws on the formation and registration of political parties. Under the changes, the news agency said, Mozambique's constitution now calls for full national elections conducted by secret ballot. Previously, elections were conducted by open voting. The constitution now also says political parties must represent national groups, which would forbid the forming of regional or secessionist parties, AIM said. It says all parties would be expected to have a democratic internal structure, to defend national interests and contribute toward peace and stability, according to the news agency. President Joachim Chissano said July 31 he wanted a multiparty system in time for parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for next year. He previously had opposed a multiparty system, saying it would encourage tribalism and waste the country's scarce resources. Chissano also has promised to end the civil war with the Mozambique National Resistance. The government and the rebels have held a series of peace talks this year. A multiparty system and new election laws are two key rebel demands. FRELIMO has been the sole legal political party in the southeast African nation since Mozambique gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The party was Marxist, but has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. The party's Central Committee approved resolutions in August that suggested any new laws should prohibit parties set up on racial, ethnic, regional or religious lines. The resolutions also suggested a new party require proven support from at least 100 people of voting age from each of the country's 11 provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Genteel Canadian City Braces for Yankee Bullfrog Invasion
DOC.TEXT: People have been jumpy around here ever since the big American bullfrogs arrived. Until recent times this Canadian provincial capital, known for its gracious homes and the venerable Empress Hotel, was a genteel place with small, quiet, insect-eating frogs. But then those big, loud outsiders that can even eat birds arrived. And now things are getting worse. The Capital Regional District's parks committee has been advised to brace for an American bullfrog population explosion this year. It's never been clearly established how the frogs got to Victoria. But Fran Benton, a part-time naturalist at the Swan Lake-Christmas Hill Nature Sanctuary, said a would-be frog farmer told her he imported them with plans of making big sales to local restaurants. When that failed, she said, he dumped them in local lakes. Two teen-agers also admitted to bringing them in from Vancouver, where they have also become well established, she said. The frogs, which can grow to 18 inches long counting their long legs, are capable of eating birds as big as orioles and robins, said Royal B.C. Museum herpetologist Stan Orchard. They also eat ducklings, which they grab by the feet and pull under water. The only viable control measure is ``going out at night and clubbing them to death,'' said Orchard, who added that some people might not like that.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Russia Movement Holds First Congress
With AM-Gorbachev-Analysis, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The opening congress of the Democratic Russia Movement, designed to rival the Communist Party, got off to a rocky start Saturday as one of the key players said he could not support a proposed founding charter. The opening of the two-day congress in downtown Moscow was attended by about 2,000 delegates, including legislators in the national and Russian Federation parliaments, and members of the Leningrad and Moscow city councils. Nikolai Travkin - the founder of the Democratic Party, which supports candidates who oppose the Communist Party - said he did not support the formation of a yet another party. Travkin said he would prefer to see a loosely organized mass movement instead. ``We will form an organizing structure'' to support candidates and print and disseminate newspapers, Travkin said in an opening speech at the congress. He said he did not endorse a charter drafted by the two other groups that helped organize the congress, the Social Democratic Party and the Christian Democratic Party. Travkin appeared to be hesitating at the last minute to subsume his own, tightly disciplined, organization into a larger party. One delegate said that many of those attending the congress had formed their own small groups and were reluctant to give up their new-found independence after 73 years of Communist rule. ``People have a fear of parties,'' said Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, one of the leaders of the exodus from the Communist Party during the summer. ``We are fighting against this anti-party sentiment,'' he said, predicting that the Democratic Russia Movement would end up, at least in the short term, as just that - a movement rather than a formal party. Lev Ponomarev, deputy chairman of the organizing committee, said in the first speech at the congress that the Democratic Russia Movement ``considers itself as an alternative to the Soviet Communist Party.'' Ponomarev said the movement does not see itself as a new political party, but rather a grouping of democratic forces opposed to mainstream communism. He said a de facto two-party system had emerged in Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, following elections in March 1989. Neither the movement nor the groups that make it up comes close to the Soviet Communist Party's membership rolls of 18 million. ``On the one side is the conservative wing of the Communist Party, on the other side are the democratic alliances,'' he said. Noticeably absent from the meeting were the three most important politicians who quit the Communist Party during the summer: Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin, Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak. A close aide to Yeltsin, Oleg Rumyantsev, said that Yeltsin was ill and could not attend the congress but that he supported the movement. Popov delegated one of his deputies, Mikhail Schneider, to read a speech strongly endorsing the Democratic Russia Movement. The delegates included representatives of grass-roots movements and new political parties, including the Interregional Deputies Group, consisting of radical reformers in the national legislature, and the Christian Democratic Movement. The Soviet state news agency Tass said the movement had the potential of becoming the second largest political force in the country after the Communist Party.
